2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: Imagine you’re doing an activity that’s full of restrictions and limitations. Is it fun? Are you enjoying this activity? Did you imagine you were … playing a game? Probably not.
2020-06-11.headline_main: How Joy Grows in the Space Between a Game’s Rules

2020-06-11.headline_main: These Authors Are Glad You’re Buying Their Books. Now Do the Work.

2020-06-11.abstract: The pandemic sparked chin-up gestures like a ‘good news’ YouTube channel. Two months later, mere gestures seem pretty empty.
2020-06-11.snippet: The pandemic sparked chin-up gestures like a ‘good news’ YouTube channel. Two months later, mere gestures seem pretty empty.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: For two months, John Krasinski looked on the bright side. Beginning in late March and ending in late May, the actor served as the anchor for eight episodes of a YouTube show he called “Some Good News,” or “S.G.N.” for short — about 20 minutes, each week, focused entirely on feel-good content. The show was a never-ending D-block, as if that final, uplifting section of a news broadcast had been stocked with dancing health professionals and put on an endless loop.
2020-06-11.headline_main: The Hollow Inspiration of ‘Some Good News’

2020-06-11.abstract: Local governments should not shore up their budgets by preying on the very people Covid-19 hit the hardest.
2020-06-11.snippet: Local governments should not shore up their budgets by preying on the very people Covid-19 hit the hardest.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: I coined the term “predatory cities” to describe urban areas where public officials systematically take property from residents and transfer it to public coffers, intentionally or unintentionally violating domestic laws or basic human rights.
2020-06-11.headline_main: The Scandal of the Predatory City

2020-06-11.abstract: E.L. Doctorow’s warmly personal and urgently hopeful speech to his alma mater, Bronx Science, is as pertinent now as it was nearly a decade ago.
2020-06-11.snippet: E.L. Doctorow’s warmly personal and urgently hopeful speech to his alma mater, Bronx Science, is as pertinent now as it was nearly a decade ago.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: E.L. Doctorow was born and grew up in the Bronx, where in the 1940s, he attended the Bronx High School of Science, a top public school founded in 1938 whose entrance requirements were stringent even then. He did not become a scientist, but as the author of “The Book of Daniel,” “Ragtime,” “World’s Fair,” “Billy Bathgate,” “The March” and many other novels, he was the winner of the National Book Award, three National Book Critics Circle Awards and two PEN/Faulkner Awards.
2020-06-11.headline_main: A Master Storyteller’s Advice for Graduates: ‘Be Brave. Be Kind.’

2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: According to Nancy Lublin, the chief executive and co-founder of Crisis Text Line, a free mental health texting service providing confidential crisis intervention, the top three topics in conversations since the pandemic began have been “anxiety,” “depression” and “relationships.”
2020-06-11.headline_main: What’s Worrying Teenagers Right Now

2020-06-11.snippet: What to watch, where to watch it, where to buy itand what the heck is going on.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: From shows to shopping to seasons to supply chains, the coronavirus has meant the end of the fashion world as we knew it. Instead we’re about to get movies! And playlists! And a lot less stuff! Here’s everything you need to know about what is happening next, updated with new information as it evolves.
2020-06-11.headline_main: The Fashion Schedule: An Opinionated Guide

2020-06-11.abstract: He has nothing but contempt for the institutions that exist to keep presidents in check.
2020-06-11.snippet: He has nothing but contempt for the institutions that exist to keep presidents in check.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: The lies and obfuscations pile up. No, it wasn’t tear gas used to clear Lafayette Park for President Trump’s Bible-waving photo-op last Monday night, Attorney General William Barr said on CBS’s “Face the Nation” on Sunday. Rather it was “pepper balls,” he said. “Pepper spray is not a chemical irritant. It’s not chemical.” Wrong, according to The Washington Post; pepper balls are very much a chemical irritant. The paper awarded the nation’s top law enforcement officer four Pinocchios for his claim.
2020-06-11.headline_main: Why Does Trump Lie?

2020-06-11.abstract: A poem that asks our most present questions: What comes next? Who knows what?
2020-06-11.snippet: A poem that asks our most present questions: What comes next? Who knows what?
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: Having met lions only from a distance in zoos, I did not consider that in the wild they can carry the scent of the dead prey they have recently consumed, and thereby stink. Poems can give us new information. The idea that something haunting and dangerous strolls through the camp at night, though, feels like recent days — tented up against the virus, we sleep our fitful sleeps. Patricia Kirkpatrick’s splendid new book, “Blood Moon,” carries us away to so many places and helps us “see farther” indeed, even asking our most present questions. What comes next? Who knows what? Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye
2020-06-11.headline_main: Poem: Lion

2020-06-11.abstract: My father the doctor maintained that hand-washing was our family’s single greatest obligation to one another and to the world. Is there any hope we’ll all keep doing it?
2020-06-11.snippet: My father the doctor maintained that hand-washing was our family’s single greatest obligation to one another and to the world. Is there any hope we’ll all keep doing it?
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: My neurologist father maintained that hand-washing was our family’s single greatest obligation to one another and to the world. “As you know, it’s the No. 1 way to prevent disease transmission,” Dr. Beauregard Lee Bercaw would say to my brother and me every single night before sitting down to dinner. “Your hands are clean, right?”
2020-06-11.headline_main: The Hand-Washing Wars

2020-06-11.abstract: The PGA Tour’s first event in three months will be contested without fans, fist bumps or Tiger Woods. But even with constraints, golfers are eager to play.
2020-06-11.snippet: The PGA Tour’s first event in three months will be contested without fans, fist bumps or Tiger Woods. But even with constraints, golfers are eager to play.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: The PGA Tour returns from a 90-day layoff on Thursday with a tournament in Fort Worth that will be contested without spectators and with one new golfing ritual: Players are directed to sanitize their hands after every hole while their caddies wipe down golf bags with disinfectant.
2020-06-11.headline_main: Golf’s Return Draws a Star-Studded Field and a Prickly Entrance Test

2020-06-11.snippet: The presumptive Democratic nominee relies on veteran advisers with Washington roots and has begun sounding out other economists on the ideological left, but his campaign will not say who really has his ear.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Few aspects of Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s presidential campaign are shrouded in as much secrecy as the counsel he receives on the economy: which advisers have the most sway with the presumptive Democratic nominee, what ideas have the greatest currency, and what new policies Mr. Biden will ultimately embrace to address the racial inequities now animating protests nationwide.

2020-06-11.abstract: Board games can provide loads of fun, but taking them too seriously can lead to tears and long-running feuds.
2020-06-11.snippet: Board games can provide loads of fun, but taking them too seriously can lead to tears and long-running feuds.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: In the best of times, a board game can provide hours of entertainment, filled with camaraderie and tests of wits and guile, thrilling twists of fate and daring acts of strategy and, of course, friendly competition. But a game also comes with a note of danger: Throw yourself into it too deeply, and it’s easy to blur that line between the game sphere — where attacking, undermining or stealing from your loved ones is not only acceptable but encouraged — and the real world, where it is decidedly not.
2020-06-11.headline_main: It’s Only a Game! Or So They Say

2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: Even as much of the world is still reeling from the coronavirus pandemic, people across the United States have taken to the streets, calling for racial justice and an end to police brutality. We asked 16 poets, including Rita Dove, Kwame Alexander, Joy Harjo and Arthur Sze, about the poets and poetry they’re reading in this time of upheaval.
2020-06-11.headline_main: The Poems That Poets Turn to in a Time of Strife

2020-06-11.abstract: While some lawmakers want to continue substantial aid for millions of unemployed workers, others are concerned that the money is holding back a recovery that depends on employees returning to work.
2020-06-11.snippet: While some lawmakers want to continue substantial aid for millions of unemployed workers, others are concerned that the money is holding back a recovery that depends on employees returning to work.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With expanded jobless benefits put in place to help laid-off workers weather the pandemic set to expire by the end of July, Republicans and Democrats in Congress are at odds over whether to continue to provide substantial payments to tens of millions of Americans who are still out of work.
2020-06-11.headline_main: With Jobless Benefits Set to Lapse, Congress Is at Odds Over an Extension

2020-06-11.abstract: The Game Maker for The New York Times (Yes! There is a Game Maker) explains.
2020-06-11.snippet: The Game Maker for The New York Times (Yes! There is a Game Maker) explains.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: Why do people love games? As the Game Maker for The New York Times, I grapple with this question every day. The reductively easy answer is simple: They’re fun! But why are they fun? Do they have to be fun? As we dig deeper and deeper, we find more questions. What even is a game? What is fun? My take on the appeal of games is also simple, if paradoxical. Games are a controlled form of freedom. Our brains grab onto them because they are structures that exist to be avoided.
2020-06-11.headline_main: Why Do People Love Games?

2020-06-11.abstract: Trying to cut spending as the pandemic reduces tax revenue, governments are finding it easier to lift restraints on what consumers pay for fuel.
2020-06-11.snippet: Trying to cut spending as the pandemic reduces tax revenue, governments are finding it easier to lift restraints on what consumers pay for fuel.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has sent economies into recession and reduced government revenue, so some countries are taking a politically perilous path: removing restraints on electricity and petroleum prices.
2020-06-11.headline_main: As Energy Prices Tumble, Developing Countries Trim Subsidies

2020-06-11.abstract: Recreational vehicles were gaining in popularity before the pandemic. Now, with travel restrictions loosening, a surge of travelers is drawn to the relative solitude that R.V.s offer.

2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: Since selling their home in Fort Collins, Colo., in September 2018, Tom and Mona Mesereau have logged 18,000 miles through 30 states in their 32-foot Class A recreational vehicle, running their public relations business from the road.

2020-06-11.abstract: The coronavirus has led to the collapse of New York’s usual admissions system, and protests against racism have highlighted entrenched division.
2020-06-11.snippet: The coronavirus has led to the collapse of New York’s usual admissions system, and protests against racism have highlighted entrenched division.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: When New York City became the national epicenter of the coronavirus pandemic, its once-sacrosanct practice of sorting thousands of children into selective public schools suddenly collapsed: The metrics that dictate admissions evaporated as schools shuttered.
2020-06-11.headline_main: A School Admissions Process That Caused Segregation Fell Apart in Weeks

2020-06-11.abstract: Those who want to remake a police model that has set off unrest and despair would do well to look at the experiences of Asia, Africa and Europe.

2020-06-11.snippet: Following an Oakland tavern and its staff — from the tattooed bartender to the undocumented cleaner — as they weather the economic and emotional fallout of the coronavirus.

2020-06-11.headline_main: One Bar. Twelve Weeks. Seventeen Lives in Lockdown.

2020-06-11.abstract: And what else you need to know today.
2020-06-11.snippet: And what else you need to know today.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: We journalists don’t always pay enough attention to good news. So I want to highlight some this morning: Across much of the United States and Europe, the coronavirus has been spreading less rapidly than many people feared.

2020-06-11.abstract: Philip Manshaus admitted to killing his stepsister and storming a mosque near Oslo last year, saying he was inspired by other far-right attacks.
2020-06-11.snippet: Philip Manshaus admitted to killing his stepsister and storming a mosque near Oslo last year, saying he was inspired by other far-right attacks.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: OSLO — A 22-year-old Norwegian man who said he was inspired by far-right attacks was sentenced on Thursday to 21 years in prison after being convicted of killing his stepsister and opening fire in a mosque near Oslo last August.
2020-06-11.headline_main: Norway Mosque Attacker Gets 21-Year Sentence

2020-06-11.abstract: In Jeremy Hersh’s film, a woman agrees to carry a child for a gay couple, and unexpected conflicts arise.
2020-06-11.snippet: In Jeremy Hersh’s film, a woman agrees to carry a child for a gay couple, and unexpected conflicts arise.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: “The Surrogate” feels like the vexed progeny of an elevator pitch and an ethics advice column. Written and directed by Jeremy Hersh, the movie begins with a scene of its heroine, Jess (Jasmine Batchelor) on a date. Her suitor is ardent, and she’s trying to make clear that what he takes for ambivalence is something different. One senses she gets this a lot, appealing as she is. There’s a hard cut to black and then Jess is rejoicing over the positive results of a pregnancy test.
2020-06-11.headline_main: ‘The Surrogate’ Review: Carrying a Baby, and Much More

2020-06-11.abstract: Hong Sang-soo’s film, structured as a letter with the pages out of order, is one of his most daring gambits.
2020-06-11.snippet: Hong Sang-soo’s film, structured as a letter with the pages out of order, is one of his most daring gambits.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: The South Korean director Hong Sang-soo, who began his career completing films at a relatively swift pace, has been on a real tear lately. Because of the vicissitudes of distribution, viewers in the United States who follow his work are catching up with it out of production order. “Yourself and Yours,” reviewed last week, was made in 2016, and this week’s “Hill of Freedom” in 2014.
2020-06-11.headline_main: ‘Hill of Freedom’ Review: A Lover’s Frustrated Quest

2020-06-11.abstract: Boaz Yakin’s movie is fresh in two ways: in its questioning of gender, and in its use of dance as a primary mode of expression.
2020-06-11.snippet: Boaz Yakin’s movie is fresh in two ways: in its questioning of gender, and in its use of dance as a primary mode of expression.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: At the heart of “Aviva” is a familiar love story between a man and a woman, with a familiar arc of romance, breakup and reconciliation. Yet in its first frames, the movie, written and directed by Boaz Yakin, announces several ways that the telling will be unusual. A naked woman looks at the camera and informs us that the character she plays is a man.
2020-06-11.headline_main: ‘Aviva’ Review: Just the Two of Us (and Our Other Selves)

2020-06-11.abstract: In plain vérité style, the documentary follows an Arrernte Aboriginal family in Alice Springs, Australia.
2020-06-11.snippet: In plain vérité style, the documentary follows an Arrernte Aboriginal family in Alice Springs, Australia.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: Colonialism is a war that began hundreds of years ago and never ended. Its modern tactics and its weapons are noted with precision in the ferocious documentary, “In My Blood It Runs.”
2020-06-11.headline_main: ‘In My Blood It Runs’ Review: ‘I Want to Be an Aborigine’

2020-06-11.abstract: At the end of her life, a dog reflects on happiness and heartbreak. But the film stays buoyant through its unique and lively animation.

2020-06-11.headline_main: ‘Marona’s Fantastic Tale’ Review: A Dog’s Life for Better or Worse

2020-06-11.abstract: The operation is believed to be the first of its kind in the U.S. The patient, a woman in her 20s, had been healthy, but the coronavirus devastated her lungs.
2020-06-11.snippet: The operation is believed to be the first of its kind in the U.S. The patient, a woman in her 20s, had been healthy, but the coronavirus devastated her lungs.

2020-06-11.abstract: Activists are using balloons to send leaflets across the border denouncing Kim Jong-un. To keep the peace, South Korea wants to stop them.
2020-06-11.snippet: Activists are using balloons to send leaflets across the border denouncing Kim Jong-un. To keep the peace, South Korea wants to stop them.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The hydrogen balloons float over the world’s most heavily guarded border, unleashing their payloads in North Korea like snowflakes: propaganda leaflets calling Kim Jong-un, the North’s leader, a “devil” who will meet the same bloody end as Saddam Hussein of Iraq and Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya.
2020-06-11.headline_main: As Floating Propaganda Irks North Korea, the South Isn’t Happy Either

2020-06-11.abstract: Renee Dutcher and Teo Alfero have learned to be better partners and parents in their work rescuing, rehabilitating and training wolf-dogs at their California sanctuary.
2020-06-11.snippet: Renee Dutcher and Teo Alfero have learned to be better partners and parents in their work rescuing, rehabilitating and training wolf-dogs at their California sanctuary.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: Renee Dutcher and Teo Alfero were married outside a tepee on the eve of a full moon, after being walked down the aisle with two of their rescued wolf-dog hybrids. Their wedding, highlighted in a Vows column on May 31, 2013, was held at Wolf Connection, a nonprofit sanctuary in Acton, Calif., founded by Mr. Alfero in 2009. The sanctuary rescues and rehabilitates wolf-dogs and uses those considered safe in programs to help at-risk youth. The couple then lived on the 28-acre wooded compound in a 30-foot trailer, without plumbing or electrical lines of its own.
2020-06-11.headline_main: Lessons on Marriage and Life from the Wolf-Dogs

2020-06-11.snippet: Poaching of the big cats is on the rise, and a new study links their slaughter to corruption as well as investment from Chinese companies.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: In May 2019, a headless jaguar carcass turned up at a garbage dump in southern Belize. The killing, one in a series of similar incidents, added to local outrage and inspired authorities, private citizens and companies to offer a combined $8,000 reward for information leading to the arrest of the jaguar killer.
2020-06-11.headline_main: Where Jaguars Are Killed, New Common Factor Emerges: Chinese Investment

2020-06-11.snippet: President Trump’s walk across Lafayette Square, current and former military leaders say, has started a moment of reckoning in the military.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The country’s top military official apologized on Thursday for taking part in President Trump’s walk across Lafayette Square for a photo op after the authorities used tear gas and rubber bullets to clear the area of peaceful protesters.

2020-06-11.abstract: Our city is a coronavirus hot spot. We were only trying to protect him.
2020-06-11.snippet: Our city is a coronavirus hot spot. We were only trying to protect him.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: Our 16-year-old son asked us if he could attend a Black Lives Matter protest march in our city, a Covid-19 hot spot. We said no. We decided it was too dangerous in terms of coronavirus risk and possible violence. He sneaked out of the apartment and went anyway. He claims he wore a mask and was socially distant the whole time, but we’re not sure whether to believe him or how to punish him. Any advice?
2020-06-11.headline_main: We Told Our Son Not to Protest. He Did Anyway. Now What?

2020-06-11.snippet: The European Commission plans to bring charges that Amazon abused its dominance in e-commerce.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: LONDON — European Union officials are preparing to bring antitrust charges against Amazon for abusing its dominance in internet commerce to box out smaller rivals, according to people with knowledge of the case.
2020-06-11.headline_main: Amazon Set to Face Antitrust Charges in European Union

2020-06-11.abstract: The International Criminal Court has collected evidence of what it says is torture, rape and other crimes by American forces during the war in Afghanistan.
2020-06-11.snippet: The International Criminal Court has collected evidence of what it says is torture, rape and other crimes by American forces during the war in Afghanistan.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — International investigators looking into charges of war crimes by Americans in Afghanistan will face economic penalties and travel restrictions, the Trump administration warned on Thursday, accusing a Hague-based court of corruption and maintaining that the United States can prosecute its own military and intelligence personnel.
2020-06-11.headline_main: U.S. to Penalize War Crimes Investigators Looking Into American Troops

2020-06-11.abstract: Daniel Karslake’s documentary follows four families navigating issues of faith in relation to the sexual orientations and gender identities of their children.
2020-06-11.snippet: Daniel Karslake’s documentary follows four families navigating issues of faith in relation to the sexual orientations and gender identities of their children.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: On June 26, 2015, hundreds of people gathered in front of the Supreme Court in anticipation of its decision to legalize same-sex marriage. It was a watershed moment that, in the words of former President Barack Obama, marked “a big step in our march toward equality.” But it was just the beginning. “For They Know Not What They Do,” a compelling documentary by Daniel Karslake, outlines the uneven path toward progress for L.G.B.T.Q. people in the United States by following four families navigating issues of faith in relation to the sexual orientations and gender identities of their children.
2020-06-11.headline_main: ‘For They Know Not What They Do’ Review: Where Faith Meets L.G.B.T.Q. Life

2020-06-11.abstract: An officer replied, “I don’t care,” and the man, Derrick Scott, died shortly afterward. This week, the Oklahoma City police released recordings of the May 2019 arrest.
2020-06-11.snippet: An officer replied, “I don’t care,” and the man, Derrick Scott, died shortly afterward. This week, the Oklahoma City police released recordings of the May 2019 arrest.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: The Oklahoma City Police Department this week released video of the arrest of a black man last year in which he can be seen pinned on the ground, saying, “I can’t breathe,” and an officer replies, “I don’t care.” The man died in custody shortly afterward.
2020-06-11.headline_main: Video Shows Black Man Pleading ‘I Can’t Breathe’ During 2019 Arrest in Oklahoma

2020-06-11.abstract: After the loss of her husband and a pandemic lockdown, this ardent activist was creatively blocked. Now, after watching the protests, she is inspired again.
2020-06-11.snippet: After the loss of her husband and a pandemic lockdown, this ardent activist was creatively blocked. Now, after watching the protests, she is inspired again.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: ENGLEWOOD, N.J. — Faith Ringgold has seen plenty of shake-ups and strange moments in her 89 well-traveled years. But the provocative Harlem-born artist — who has confronted race relations in this country from every angle, led protests to diversify museums decades ago, and even went to jail for an exhibition she organized — has had no reference point for the pandemic keeping her in lockdown and creatively paralyzed in her home in this leafy suburb for much of the spring.
2020-06-11.headline_main: Faith Ringgold Will Keep Fighting Back

2020-06-11.abstract: Kenneth Branagh’s film has no reason to exist, other than to spawn sequels.
2020-06-11.snippet: Kenneth Branagh’s film has no reason to exist, other than to spawn sequels.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: Few filmmaking trajectories in recent decades have been as perplexing as that of Kenneth Branagh, who once impressed critics as a superior director of Shakespeare. If his literary side hasn’t fully receded — lately his taste runs to Agatha Christie — on a bad day, he goes mercenary, stewarding properties like “Thor,” Jack Ryan and now “Artemis Fowl” (streaming on Disney Plus). The latest movie, based on a novel in the young-adult series by Eoin Colfer, projects absolutely nothing beyond a desire to kick-start a new hotshot franchise: Coming soon! Seven sequels. Insert original here.
2020-06-11.headline_main: ‘Artemis Fowl’ Review: Fowl, Not Fair

2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: Over the last two weeks, the number of Americans who have downloaded Signal, an encrypted messaging application, has skyrocketed. Many are using the app to organize and participate in protests against police brutality (without being spied on by law enforcement).
2020-06-11.headline_main: Signal Downloads Are Way Up Since the Protests Began

2020-06-11.abstract: Once upon a time you could drop a dime in a movie jukebox to hear — and watch — musical greats like Duke Ellington and Gene Krupa.
2020-06-11.snippet: Once upon a time you could drop a dime in a movie jukebox to hear — and watch — musical greats like Duke Ellington and Gene Krupa.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: Hair slicked and smile set to dazzle, Duke Ellington is standing at an upright piano when “Hot Chocolate” opens, conducting a band that’s already swinging. A decorative musical staff provides the only ornamentation on the otherwise bare-bones, cramped set. That scarcely matters because Ellington is playing. He calls out Ben Webster’s name and there’s a cut to the saxophonist. A few more cuts take us to two women who smile and nod, then Whitey’s Lindy Hoppers begin jumping, rocketing the film into the stratosphere.
2020-06-11.headline_main: The Swinging, Jamming Musical Charms of 1940s Soundies

2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: With cities starting to reopen after months of pandemic-prescribed lockdown, people are talking about office life. The open-floor plan so beloved of managers is likely to be a thing of the past, replaced by Plexiglas barriers or work-from-home video links. These changes, combined with a spate of highly publicized worker revolts tied to diversity issues, suggest that the old office norms are under siege, which makes it seem like a good time to revisit “Nine to Five.”

Where do all the black dancers and choreographers of the past several decades fit in to the history of American dance?” The question drove him to become a dance scholar.

2020-06-11.abstract: There’s “no nook or cranny” on the planet where it doesn’t end up, the lead researcher on a new study said.
2020-06-11.snippet: There’s “no nook or cranny” on the planet where it doesn’t end up, the lead researcher on a new study said.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: Plastic pollution isn’t just fouling the world’s oceans. It is also in the air we breathe, traveling on the wind and drifting down from the skies, according to a new study. More than 1,000 tons of tiny fragments rain down each year on national parks and wilderness areas in the American West alone, equivalent to between 123 million and 300 million plastic bottles worth.
2020-06-11.headline_main: Where’s Airborne Plastic? Everywhere, Scientists Find.

As an antidote, he favors lower-budget productions, reserving special affection for a group of independent directors who attended film school at the University of California, Los Angeles, and became collectively known as the L.A. Rebellion.

2020-06-11.abstract: As cultural institutions scramble to declare their support for Black Lives Matter, their gestures have felt both self-aggrandizing and too little too late.
2020-06-11.snippet: As cultural institutions scramble to declare their support for Black Lives Matter, their gestures have felt both self-aggrandizing and too little too late.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: The protests sparked by the public killing of George Floyd in police custody have added up, day by day, to a history-altering human rights movement, potentially the most consequential of the past 50 years. But they’ve left some of our history-writing and history-preserving institutions scrambling to find ways to join.
2020-06-11.headline_main: Museums Are Finally Taking a Stand. But Can They Find Their Footing?

2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: The political calendar is a bit like the liturgical calendar: People pay more attention when a big event is on the horizon (Election Day, Christmas), but the most meaningful experiences often occur on their own schedule, in reaction to private or unplanned happenstance. A death, a disaster — that’s when you see protests, or conversions, start to take hold.

2020-06-11.abstract: At a time when caricatures were a regular part of the nation’s sports pages, Mr. Olderman thrived as a cartoonist. He also wrote features and columns.
2020-06-11.snippet: At a time when caricatures were a regular part of the nation’s sports pages, Mr. Olderman thrived as a cartoonist. He also wrote features and columns.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: Murray Olderman, who chronicled the sports world as what he called a “rare double threat,” turning out nationally syndicated cartoons while also writing features and columns in a career of more than 60 years, died on Wednesday in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 98.
2020-06-11.headline_main: Murray Olderman, Who Both Wrote and Drew About Sports, Dies at 98

2020-06-11.abstract: Cauleen Smith’s experimental films about black life, Kyle Marshall’s dance improvisation dedicated to victims of police brutality: Here are some of the Instagram accounts brightening our art critic’s daily feed.
2020-06-11.snippet: Cauleen Smith’s experimental films about black life, Kyle Marshall’s dance improvisation dedicated to victims of police brutality: Here are some of the Instagram accounts brightening our art critic’s daily feed.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: For the past couple months, my Instagram feed has been filled with benign photographs of homemade food, flowering plants, and the creative projects people had undertaken while in coronavirus-mandated lockdown. Then, on May 25, George Floyd was killed in police custody in Minneapolis, sparking protests around the country. Instagram had already been a space for organizing and activism, but overnight that seemed to become its primary purpose. Calls to action, pictures and videos from demonstrations, and educational posts about defunding the police flooded into view.
2020-06-11.headline_main: Five Art Accounts to Follow on Instagram Now

2020-06-11.abstract: We studied 26 million Americans over 12 years. Here’s what we learned about gun ownership.

2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans have experienced the coronavirus pandemic directly, as they or their loved ones suffered through infection. But for most of us, the experience is defined by weeks and months on end stuck at home. The shut-ins are testing the safety of our home environments. Stress and isolation combined with another feature of American life — easy access to firearms — could form a deadly brew.
2020-06-11.headline_main: Coronavirus Could Make America’s Gun Problem Even Deadlier

2020-06-11.abstract: Progressive ideas don’t just turn out the vote. They win votes.
2020-06-11.snippet: Progressive ideas don’t just turn out the vote. They win votes.
2020-06-11.lead_paragraph: Joe Biden is the Democratic presidential nominee, and though the primary was, by historical standards, quite tepid, there is still a lot of work to be done on unifying the party. Many young Democrats are rightfully skeptical of Mr. Biden and his record on many issues that matter to them. But Mr. Biden’s team has at its disposal a number of concrete actions that would not just help to unite the party but also help it win persuadable voters. By embracing progressive ideas, Mr. Biden and his allies will be able to make a persuasive positive case for himself that will appeal to voters, as opposed to just focusing on anti-Trump messaging that isn’t as persuasive. Research, in fact, shows that most voters have fairly fixed views on Mr. Trump but can be persuaded about Mr. Biden.
2020-06-11.headline_main: Why Joe Biden Should Look to His Left

2020-06-11.abstract: Astrobotic, a Pittsburgh company, won a $199.5 million contract to transport NASA’s VIPER rover to the lunar surface.

2020-06-12.abstract: A reckoning has come to Bon Appétit and the other magazines of Condé Nast. Can a culture built on elitism and exclusion possibly change?
2020-06-12.snippet: A reckoning has come to Bon Appétit and the other magazines of Condé Nast. Can a culture built on elitism and exclusion possibly change?
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: On Monday, as swiftly as a 9-iron taken to a tee at Augusta, Adam Rapoport resigned as the editor in chief of Bon Appétit magazine after a damning Halloween photo circulated on social media that morning. Drawn from the vast insensitivity archives to which so many influential people have made inadvertent submissions, the picture, from 2004, shows him costumed in a tank top and thick chain necklace as his wife’s “papi,’’ the term she attached to it in an Instagram post several years later.
2020-06-12.headline_main: Can Anna Wintour Survive the Social Justice Movement?

2020-06-12.abstract: A racist president trolls his enemies with a rally on Juneteenth.
2020-06-12.snippet: A racist president trolls his enemies with a rally on Juneteenth.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: Most people — or, at any rate, most readers of The New York Times — remember Donald Trump’s response to the white nationalist riot in Charlottesville, Va., as a particularly low point in a presidency full of them. After a rambling, aggrieved news conference in which he defended some of those marching with neo-Nazis as “very fine people,” Trump’s already dismal approval rating hovered below 38 percent. Staffers voiced shame and disgust to journalists (anonymously, of course). Senator Susan Collins was “concerned.”
2020-06-12.headline_main: Trump’s Grotesque Tulsa Trip

2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: It doesn’t take a Modern Love column to tell you that relationships can flourish — or wither — in times of stress. Add months of isolation, the physical and emotional toll of a pandemic, followed by global protests, and this period we’re living through has the capacity to reshape relationships on a broad scale.

2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: PARIS — As France eased one of Europe’s toughest coronavirus lockdowns last month, a small army of street workers fanned out across Paris in the dark of night. They dropped traffic barriers along car lanes and painted yellow bicycle symbols onto the asphalt. By morning, miles of pop-up “corona cycleways” had been laid, teeming with people heading back to work.

He steals their light bulbs, cuts their power and locks them out of spare bathrooms when the communal latrine becomes unusable. A swift kick of frustration was all it took to make a person-size hole in its wall.

2020-06-12.abstract: Spike Lee’s latest joint hits Netflix. And the long-gestating film adaptation of the Y.A. fantasy series “Artemis Fowl” debuts on Disney Plus.
2020-06-12.snippet: Spike Lee’s latest joint hits Netflix. And the long-gestating film adaptation of the Y.A. fantasy series “Artemis Fowl” debuts on Disney Plus.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: DA 5 BLOODS (2020) Stream on Netflix. A group of Vietnam War veterans search for the bones of a fallen comrade and a box full of gold in “Da 5 Bloods,” the latest film from Spike Lee. Anchored in the present day with flashbacks to the past, the movie follows four aging former members of an Army squad — played by Delroy Lindo, Isiah Whitlock Jr., Norm Lewis and Clarke Peters — who return to Vietnam. They’re hoping to dig up the remains of their leader (Chadwick Boseman), who died during the war, and a box of gold bars that the squad had commandeered from the U.S. government, then lost. “This long, anguished, funny, violent excursion into a hidden chamber of the nation’s heart of darkness isn’t like anything else, ” A.O. Scott wrote in his review for The New York Times, “even if it may put you in mind of a lot of other things.”
2020-06-12.headline_main: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Da 5 Bloods’ and ‘Artemis Fowl’

2020-06-12.abstract: The removal of a slave trader’s statue in England begins a conversation about how we are shaped by our past and how it configures the present.
2020-06-12.snippet: The removal of a slave trader’s statue in England begins a conversation about how we are shaped by our past and how it configures the present.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: BRIGHTON, England — Tens of thousands of people protested in British cities in solidarity with those rising up against police brutality against black Americans in the past week. They highlighted similar injustices in Britain. Protesters in the city of Bristol drew connections between a white police officer’s killing of George Floyd, a black man in Minneapolis, and the histories of colonialism and the slave trade. On Sunday, they toppled the statue of Edward Colston, a 17th-century slave trader, trampled over it and rolled it into Bristol Harbor.
2020-06-12.headline_main: A Statue Was Toppled. Can We Finally Talk About the British Empire?

2020-06-12.abstract: In the first verdict of its kind, a South Korean court has ruled that Kara Bos, an American, is a daughter of an 85-year-old man in Seoul.

2020-06-12.headline_main: Korean Adoptee Wins Landmark Case in Search for Birth Parents

2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: THE PANDEMIC CENTURY: One Hundred Years of Panic, Hysteria, and Hubris, by Mark Honigsbaum. (Norton, 512 pp., $17.95.) Some scenes in this “deeply researched” history, citing similarities in the world’s response to nine so-called pandemics, are “so vivid” they had our reviewer, Carl Zimmer, “drafting movie treatments” in his head. The paperback edition includes a new chapter on the coronavirus.

2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: On a rare quiet evening in late May, Dr. Dahlia Rizk asked her staff to join her by a campfire. They sat together for more than an hour, sharing the overwhelming horrors and occasional triumphs they’d experienced while treating the coronavirus, as the sounds of burning logs crackled in the background and a bright orange glow filled the room.
2020-06-12.headline_main: How a Virus Triage Tent Became a Serene Oasis for Health Care Workers

2020-06-12.abstract: Sam Thirlwall and Caitlin Halla met at work and felt an instant connection. Slack messages became text messages became long emails, and then a first date.
2020-06-12.snippet: Sam Thirlwall and Caitlin Halla met at work and felt an instant connection. Slack messages became text messages became long emails, and then a first date.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: Everything was telling Sam Thirlwall not to take this job. Joining Zapproved, a legal services technology company in Portland, Ore., would mean a pay cut. It also would mean being a manager responsible for a large team, rather than doing what he had done for years, which was building cybersecurity software. Mr. Thirlwall, 36, didn’t know much about the company or legal technology. Even the interview process seemed weird.
2020-06-12.headline_main: A Date to Remember

2020-06-12.abstract: For that to happen, some monuments — and the historical myths they supported — are going to have to come down.
2020-06-12.snippet: For that to happen, some monuments — and the historical myths they supported — are going to have to come down.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: It doesn’t necessarily follow that a nationwide protest over police brutality would, for some, become a reason to take action against Confederate statues and other controversial monuments. But it has. In just the last week, protesters have knocked down Confederate statues in Richmond, Va., Nashville and Montgomery, Ala., as well as monuments to Christopher Columbus in Boston and St. Paul, Minn.
2020-06-12.headline_main: To Overturn Trump, We Need to Overturn White Supremacy

2020-06-12.abstract: “This is the dreaded question,” say experts struggling to weigh virus risks and uncertainty against family well-being.
2020-06-12.snippet: “This is the dreaded question,” say experts struggling to weigh virus risks and uncertainty against family well-being.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: For many parents, the most pressing question as the nation emerges from pandemic lockdown is when they can send their children to school, camp or child care.
2020-06-12.headline_main: How 132 Epidemiologists Are Deciding When to Send Their Children to School

2020-06-12.abstract: In a rare interview, the Nobel Prize winner discusses mortality, drawing inspiration from the past, and his new album, “Rough and Rowdy Ways.”
2020-06-12.snippet: In a rare interview, the Nobel Prize winner discusses mortality, drawing inspiration from the past, and his new album, “Rough and Rowdy Ways.”
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: A few years ago, sitting beneath shade trees in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., I had a two-hour discussion with Bob Dylan that touched on Malcolm X, the French Revolution, Franklin Roosevelt and World War II. At one juncture, he asked me what I knew about the Sand Creek Massacre of 1864. When I answered, “Not enough,” he got up from his folding chair, climbed into his tour bus, and came back five minutes later with photocopies describing how U.S. troops had butchered hundreds of peaceful Cheyenne and Arapahoe in southeastern Colorado.
2020-06-12.headline_main: Bob Dylan Has a Lot on His Mind

2020-06-12.abstract: Many beauty salons and barbershops are booked solid with appointments, showing how much grooming is a treasured ritual.
2020-06-12.snippet: Many beauty salons and barbershops are booked solid with appointments, showing how much grooming is a treasured ritual.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: Few professional encounters require prolonged bouts of close contact like appointments at hair or beauty salons. This makes beauty, nail and barbershops potentially high-risk hubs of infection for the coronavirus, which has killed almost half a million people worldwide since the start of this year.
2020-06-12.headline_main: Hair Salons Reopen, and Americans Rush Back

On June 1, the institution’s new director was there to welcome the first visitors back after the coronavirus lockdown. About a dozen were lining up in the sunshine, six feet apart.

2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: It’s a truism of politics: When you’ve got an incumbent on the ballot, the race will be a referendum on her or his leadership — probably more than it’ll be about what the challenger is offering. So with President Trump’s approval rating stuck deep in the red, there’s little doubt that he is facing an uphill battle.

2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: In the wake of the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis, the N.F.L., a league that has wrestled with racial issues for years, has shown unusual unity. Players, coaches, league officials and owners have expressed sadness, remorse and a commitment to seek solutions to police violence against African-American people and other forms of social injustice.
2020-06-12.headline_main: The N.F.L. Embraces Progressive Action, but Not Yet Kaepernick

2020-06-12.abstract: The president’s threat to use troops against largely peaceful protesters, as well as other attempts to politicize the military, have unsettled a number of current and former members and their families.
2020-06-12.snippet: The president’s threat to use troops against largely peaceful protesters, as well as other attempts to politicize the military, have unsettled a number of current and former members and their families.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: Erin Fangmann grew up in a military family, has been married to a captain in the Air Force for 18 years and has voted Republican all her life, including for Donald J. Trump. But as with a number of other veterans, troops and military family members who have watched the president with alarm, her support has evaporated.
2020-06-12.headline_main: Trump’s Actions Rattle the Military World: ‘I Can’t Support the Man’

2020-06-12.abstract: Many asylum-seekers work as caregivers in nursing homes on the front-lines of Canada’s coronavirus crisis. The government is considering allowing them a faster route to stay in the country.
2020-06-12.snippet: Many asylum-seekers work as caregivers in nursing homes on the front-lines of Canada’s coronavirus crisis. The government is considering allowing them a faster route to stay in the country.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — Sterly Lucien, a Haitian orderly in a Quebec nursing home, has had sleepless nights for two years, fearful that she and her young son could be deported at anytime. But the 30-year old may find reprieve from an unlikely source: the deadly coronavirus.
2020-06-12.headline_main: Risking Their Lives in Canada’s Pandemic and Hoping That’s Enough to Stay

2020-06-12.abstract: As the country grapples with racial justice, architects should finally take a stand on the most barbaric aspects of a biased prison system.
2020-06-12.snippet: As the country grapples with racial justice, architects should finally take a stand on the most barbaric aspects of a biased prison system.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: Like many organizations in the wake of George Floyd’s killing, the board of the American Institute of Architects issued a statement the other day expressing solidarity with protesters — and offering a mea culpa. “We were wrong not to address and work to correct the built world’s role in perpetuating systemic racial injustice,” the statement said. But “we support and are committed to efforts to ensure that our profession is part of the solution.”
2020-06-12.headline_main: There’s No Reason for an Architect to Design a Death Chamber

2020-06-12.abstract: Opera is often assumed to be just about bigness. But here are 10 operas where size isn’t everything.
2020-06-12.snippet: Opera is often assumed to be just about bigness. But here are 10 operas where size isn’t everything.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: Opera is often assumed to be just about bigness. Powerful voices, huge choruses and imposing orchestral forces dominate our sense of the art form.
2020-06-12.headline_main: A Grand History of Small Operas

2020-06-12.abstract: Set in a downscale New Jersey Jewish country club in the mid-1980s, the Amazon series has a laid-back, low-stakes vibe that fans of “Dazed and Confused” should appreciate.
2020-06-12.snippet: Set in a downscale New Jersey Jewish country club in the mid-1980s, the Amazon series has a laid-back, low-stakes vibe that fans of “Dazed and Confused” should appreciate.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: Within a few years after Richard Linklater’s “Dazed and Confused” tanked in theaters in 1993, cheap VHS copies were a staple of dorm rooms and off-campus housing, like shakily constructed loft beds and cereal for dinner. During that period, I was wrapping up my senior year and entering a blurry, two-year townie purgatory in Athens, Ga., before graduate school, which made me the target audience for this particular cult phenomenon. I’ve seen “Dazed and Confused” several times, but in a way I’ve seen it dozens of times because those VCRs were whirring nonstop, on the periphery of parties or other after-hours shenanigans.
2020-06-12.headline_main: Comfort Viewing: 3 Reasons I Love ‘Red Oaks’

2020-06-12.abstract: Make Samin Nosrat’s favorite kimchi pancake, from Pyeong Chang Tofu House in Oakland, Calif., or Todd Richard’s fried catfish with hot sauce.
2020-06-12.snippet: Make Samin Nosrat’s favorite kimchi pancake, from Pyeong Chang Tofu House in Oakland, Calif., or Todd Richard’s fried catfish with hot sauce.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: Good morning. Samin Nosrat has a great column this week in The Times, about trying to recreate her favorite kimchi pancake (above), the one she’s been eating at Pyeong Chang Tofu House in Oakland, Calif., for the past 20 years. She got the recipe from Young S. Kim, the restaurant’s owner and chef, then made it for neighbors with store-bought kimchi, who loved the result. Still, it didn’t taste right to Samin until she made it with some of the 1,400 pounds of kimchi that Mrs. Kim makes each month for the restaurant.
2020-06-12.headline_main: What to Cook This Weekend

2020-06-12.abstract: Who was George Floyd? A Mississippi town comes together. Bob Dylan speaks. Donna Tartt on Charles Portis. And more.

2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. Uncertainty is hard. Sitting still in what we know is so much easier. But we are not sitting still — not anymore. We’ve gone straight from lockdown and isolation to gathering in the streets. It’s a head-spinning turn. Maybe the weekend is a time to take stock. Whatever you are doing, make time for some amazing journalism.

A year and half ago, when a police officer intervened after an incident involving my disabled African-American son in a Target store, our family didn’t even get an apology.

2020-06-12.abstract: In Candace Bushnell and Katie Cotugno’s “Rules for Being a Girl,” a high school senior is delighted to be alone with a teacher she has a crush on — until he kisses her.
2020-06-12.snippet: In Candace Bushnell and Katie Cotugno’s “Rules for Being a Girl,” a high school senior is delighted to be alone with a teacher she has a crush on — until he kisses her.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: There’s a grim familiarity to stories about young girls falling prey to men in positions of power. As readers, we recognize the girl’s first heady thrill at being called special by someone who seems to have the authority above all others to declare it, and then we follow that plotline to its heart-rending conclusion. The best-selling authors Candace Bushnell and Katie Cotugno explore this territory in RULES FOR BEING A GIRL (Balzer + Bray, 304 pp., $19.99; ages 13 and up), a book so engaging and lively it might take you a moment to pinpoint the disquiet you feel upon reaching its end.
2020-06-12.headline_main: Crushing: A Schoolgirl’s Beloved Teacher Crosses the Line

2020-06-12.abstract: In Kelly Yang’s “Parachutes,” two very different girls at the same prep school take a sledgehammer to rape culture.
2020-06-12.snippet: In Kelly Yang’s “Parachutes,” two very different girls at the same prep school take a sledgehammer to rape culture.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: “You don’t have to go and ruin my life.”
2020-06-12.headline_main: Parachuting In, Then Speaking Out

2020-06-12.abstract: Melanie Greene and J. Bouey, hosts of the Dance Union podcast, are moving beyond “a lot of talking” to organize for change.
2020-06-12.snippet: Melanie Greene and J. Bouey, hosts of the Dance Union podcast, are moving beyond “a lot of talking” to organize for change.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: Fair pay for dancers, abuses of power in dance companies, racism in dance criticism: As the hosts of the Dance Union, an independent podcast started in 2018, J. Bouey and Melanie Greene are known for speaking out on topics often shrouded in silence.
2020-06-12.headline_main: A Model for the ‘Dance World We Want’

2020-06-12.abstract: Wang Linfa has researched bats and their diseases for decades, usually drawing little public attention. Now a world wracked by the coronavirus is relying on the work of scientists like him.
2020-06-12.snippet: Wang Linfa has researched bats and their diseases for decades, usually drawing little public attention. Now a world wracked by the coronavirus is relying on the work of scientists like him.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — The bat is considered lucky in China; the words for bat and good fortune sound alike in Chinese. But Wang Linfa didn’t give much thought to the order Chiroptera while growing up in Shanghai in the 1960s and ’70s, when the main sign of nighttime life was the soft whir of commuters bicycling home from factories.
2020-06-12.headline_main: Amid a Pandemic, ‘Batman’ Matters More Than Ever

2020-06-12.abstract: What’s black and white and can be turned into hours of entertainment?
2020-06-12.snippet: What’s black and white and can be turned into hours of entertainment?
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: People around the globe shell out billions of dollars each year on professionally manufactured games: According to a recent study, spending worldwide on playing cards and board games is expected to reach nearly $22 billion by the year 2025. But the truth is that you can turn anything into a game — even a newspaper! These fun hexagon tiles are flexible game components that allow for a variety of games and play styles. You can make your own by cutting up a newspaper and folding it using the instructions below.
2020-06-12.headline_main: Playing the Paper

2020-06-12.abstract: I wanted my 6-year-old to see people standing up for our rights. I felt safe because in our city, the cops are women of color, like his grandma.
2020-06-12.snippet: I wanted my 6-year-old to see people standing up for our rights. I felt safe because in our city, the cops are women of color, like his grandma.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: Last Tuesday evening I took my 6-year-old son, Javier, around our neighborhood in Jersey City and introduced him to all the “mom” cops.
2020-06-12.headline_main: Why I Took My Young Son to Protest

2020-06-12.abstract: Fry discusses “Heroes,” and Lauren Christensen and Andrew LaVallee talk about books on the subject of race and racism.
2020-06-12.snippet: Fry discusses “Heroes,” and Lauren Christensen and Andrew LaVallee talk about books on the subject of race and racism.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen
2020-06-12.headline_main: Stephen Fry on Reimagining the Greek Myths

2020-06-12.abstract: France’s Ligue 1 is the only one of Europe’s major soccer leagues to cancel its season. What nobody yet understands is why, or even who made the decision.
2020-06-12.snippet: France’s Ligue 1 is the only one of Europe’s major soccer leagues to cancel its season. What nobody yet understands is why, or even who made the decision.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Finally, it seemed, the battle was over. After a month of uncertainty and infighting and turmoil, French soccer at last had closure. The highest administrative court in the country, the Conseil d’État, had made its ruling: The soccer season was finished.
2020-06-12.headline_main: How French Soccer Fell Apart

2020-06-12.abstract: A trailblazer in a macho world, she burned up the sand at Daytona Beach, clocking in at more than 150 miles per hour.
2020-06-12.snippet: A trailblazer in a macho world, she burned up the sand at Daytona Beach, clocking in at more than 150 miles per hour.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: She was called “the fastest woman in racing” and “the fastest woman on the sand.” Her explosive speed on the hard-packed sands of Daytona Beach, Fla., in 1960, topping 150 miles per hour, earned her a place in the record books.
2020-06-12.headline_main: Vicki Wood, Who Broke Car-Racing Gender Barriers, Dies at 101

2020-06-12.abstract: A recent cyberattack that disrupted the operations of the company may have been the first time criminals used sophisticated software previously known to be used by state agents.
2020-06-12.snippet: A recent cyberattack that disrupted the operations of the company may have been the first time criminals used sophisticated software previously known to be used by state agents.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: A computer virus hit the Japanese automaker Honda this week, disrupting its internal computer networks, forcing it to shut factories across the globe and leaving employees cut off from email or internal servers.
2020-06-12.headline_main: Honda Hackers May Have Used Tools Favored by Countries

2020-06-12.abstract: They say the mayor has benefited politically from pledges to overhaul the Police Department, but has failed to deliver meaningful change.
2020-06-12.snippet: They say the mayor has benefited politically from pledges to overhaul the Police Department, but has failed to deliver meaningful change.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio looked out into a sea of protesters at a memorial with George Floyd’s brother in Brooklyn last week and delivered a bold promise: He would transform the New York Police Department. “Change that you can see and believe, because you will see it with your own eyes,” he declared.
2020-06-12.headline_main: ‘We Want to See Action’: Why Black Supporters Are Deserting de Blasio

2020-06-12.abstract: Without a union or safety net, scores of minor league players, stadium workers and club employees have borne the financial pain of the suspended M.L.B. season.
2020-06-12.snippet: Without a union or safety net, scores of minor league players, stadium workers and club employees have borne the financial pain of the suspended M.L.B. season.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: Like thousands of minor league baseball players, Zack Kelly knew May 31 was an important date. With professional baseball on pause because of the pandemic, M.L.B. had ensured minor leaguers would be paid $400 a week through the end of the month — and Kelly had a hunch that some players would be released as that expiration date approached.
2020-06-12.headline_main: As Money Squabbles Delay M.L.B., Many Workers ‘Just Get Steam-Rolled’

2020-06-12.abstract: For a crowd-pleasing treat, pack them with dried fruit, nuts or a chopped up chocolate bar.
2020-06-12.snippet: For a crowd-pleasing treat, pack them with dried fruit, nuts or a chopped up chocolate bar.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: Has everyone’s surreptitious chocolate chip consumption gone way up since we’ve all had to stay at home? Or is this phenomenon limited to my particular kitchen? And is it also why, no matter how often I replenish the stock, there’s never quite enough left in the bag whenever I try to bake cookies?
2020-06-12.headline_main: Low on Chocolate Chips? These Cookies Love a Substitution

2020-06-12.abstract: Streaming services have pulled a host of British comedy series featuring blackface. The actions highlight the fact that racist depictions weren’t just a thing of the past.
2020-06-12.snippet: Streaming services have pulled a host of British comedy series featuring blackface. The actions highlight the fact that racist depictions weren’t just a thing of the past.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: LONDON — On Thursday night, the British chat-show host Trisha Goddard discussed the impact of an impersonation of her by a white comedian in blackface that was popular on television here in the early 2000s.
2020-06-12.headline_main: Blackface on British TV Finally Faces a Reckoning

2020-06-12.abstract: The department said that comments by Maj. Travis Yates, who spoke about police shootings of African-Americans, “do not align with the mission, values or policies of the Tulsa Police.”
2020-06-12.snippet: The department said that comments by Maj. Travis Yates, who spoke about police shootings of African-Americans, “do not align with the mission, values or policies of the Tulsa Police.”
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: The Police Department in Tulsa, Okla., said it was investigating one of its officers over remarks he made in a radio interview this week in which he spoke about police shootings of black Americans, amid nationwide protests against racism and ahead of President Trump’s visit next week.
2020-06-12.headline_main: Tulsa Police Investigate Officer After Remarks About Race and Shootings

2020-06-12.abstract: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada called the video showing police officers arresting Chief Allan Adam of Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation “shocking.”

2020-06-12.abstract: Sterling Higgins, 37, appeared delusional, but the police arrested him in 2019 instead of seeking medical help, according to a lawsuit. He died shortly after his arrest, which was captured on video released Friday.
2020-06-12.snippet: Sterling Higgins, 37, appeared delusional, but the police arrested him in 2019 instead of seeking medical help, according to a lawsuit. He died shortly after his arrest, which was captured on video released Friday.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: Sterling Higgins called the police in March 2019 and told them someone was following him and trying to kill him. When officers arrived at a convenience store parking lot in northwestern Tennessee, they found Mr. Higgins distressed and yelling at a woman whom he accused of stealing from him.
2020-06-12.headline_main: A Tennessee Man Called Police for Help, Then Died in Their Custody

2020-06-12.abstract: A slice of fandom divides itself from J.K. Rowling.
2020-06-12.snippet: A slice of fandom divides itself from J.K. Rowling.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: When J.K. Rowling was accused of transphobia about two years ago for “liking” a tweet that referred to transgender women as “men in dresses,” much of the Harry Potter fandom tried to give their beloved author the benefit of the doubt. Perhaps it really was just an accident, a “clumsy and middle-aged moment,” as Ms. Rowling’s spokesperson said at the time.
2020-06-12.headline_main: Harry Potter Fans Reimagine Their World Without Its Creator

2020-06-12.abstract: Government support for banning the chokehold and disciplining officers suspected of racism drew angry pushback, placing President Emmanuel Macron in a bind and limiting the changes approved.
2020-06-12.snippet: Government support for banning the chokehold and disciplining officers suspected of racism drew angry pushback, placing President Emmanuel Macron in a bind and limiting the changes approved.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French police, furious at a popular backlash against them in the wake of the George Floyd killing, have pushed back against government attempts to change their practices and discipline officers suspected of racism, demonstrating Friday in Paris and throwing down handcuffs in front of police stations all over France.
2020-06-12.headline_main: French Police Push Back Against Proposed Reforms

2020-06-12.abstract: In announcing the reversal, the coffee chain also said it would make 250,000 Black Lives Matter shirts for baristas who wanted them.
2020-06-12.snippet: In announcing the reversal, the coffee chain also said it would make 250,000 Black Lives Matter shirts for baristas who wanted them.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: Starbucks said on Friday that employees would be allowed to wear Black Lives Matter shirts and pins, a sudden reversal of a company policy that had banned the phrase because it could “amplify divisiveness.”
2020-06-12.headline_main: Starbucks Will Allow Employees to Wear Black Lives Matter Apparel

2020-06-12.abstract: When its equipment sales to bars and restaurants plummeted during the pandemic, Cocktail Kingdom successfully turned to consumers.
2020-06-12.snippet: When its equipment sales to bars and restaurants plummeted during the pandemic, Cocktail Kingdom successfully turned to consumers.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: This article is part of Owning the Future, a series on how small businesses across the country are coping with the coronavirus pandemic.
2020-06-12.headline_main: A Barware Company for the Pros Adds Amateurs to the Mix

2020-06-12.abstract: Citing the coronavirus, at least 12 Russian cities will skip military parades that President Vladimir Putin set for June 24, hoping to boost his image before a national referendum.
2020-06-12.snippet: Citing the coronavirus, at least 12 Russian cities will skip military parades that President Vladimir Putin set for June 24, hoping to boost his image before a national referendum.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — When President Vladimir V. Putin ordered Russia’s annual military parade to be rescheduled for later this month, he cast it as a sign of life returning to normal in his virus-stricken nation.
2020-06-12.headline_main: Putin Wants Parades Ahead of Key Vote. Local Officials Aren’t So Sure.

2020-06-12.abstract: His research into dopamine led to the mainstay treatment still used today to treat millions of people with Parkinson’s.
2020-06-12.snippet: His research into dopamine led to the mainstay treatment still used today to treat millions of people with Parkinson’s.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: Oleh Hornykiewicz, a pharmacologist whose breakthrough research on Parkinson’s disease has spared millions of patients the tremors and other physical impairments it can cause, died on May 26 in Vienna. He was 93.
2020-06-12.headline_main: Oleh Hornykiewicz, Who Discovered Parkinson’s Treatment, Dies at 93

2020-06-12.abstract: In a briefing, officials said the “highest risk”gatherings are those attended by people from outside the local area and where it is hard to stay six feet apart.
2020-06-12.snippet: In a briefing, officials said the “highest risk”gatherings are those attended by people from outside the local area and where it is hard to stay six feet apart.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: Three months after the country’s top public health agency, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, abruptly stopped holding regular briefings on the coronavirus pandemic, its director, Dr. Robert Redfield, restarted them on Friday amid growing calls for the agency to claim a more prominent role in the virus response.
2020-06-12.headline_main: C.D.C. Calls for Masks at Large Gatherings, Warning of Crowd Risks

2020-06-12.abstract: The State Department says it could take up to eight weeks to process passport applications that have piled up during consular closings caused by the coronavirus.
2020-06-12.snippet: The State Department says it could take up to eight weeks to process passport applications that have piled up during consular closings caused by the coronavirus.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sarah Farris, an American living in Singapore, rushed to her parents’ home in Florida in April to see her father before he died. She is now stuck, unable to return to her job, because she has been unable to renew her expiring passport.
2020-06-12.headline_main: Virus Delays Passports for 1.7 Million Americans

2020-06-12.abstract: The March 21 closure of the Canada-U. S. border has led to a drastic downturn in traffic and speculation about what will happen when the shutdown is set to expire.
2020-06-12.snippet: The March 21 closure of the Canada-U. S. border has led to a drastic downturn in traffic and speculation about what will happen when the shutdown is set to expire.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: This week Prime Minister Justin Trudeau may have resolved some of the concerns Canada Letter readers have raised in emails about the border closing with the United States. A tweak to its rules now means that married and common law couples who had found themselves unable to reunite if they weren’t both Canadian citizens can now do so.
2020-06-12.headline_main: How Much Longer Will the Border Stay Shut?

2020-06-12.abstract: Mrs. Trump used her husband’s victory in November 2016 as an opportunity to solidify her financial standing, for herself and for the couple’s son, Barron, the book says.
2020-06-12.snippet: Mrs. Trump used her husband’s victory in November 2016 as an opportunity to solidify her financial standing, for herself and for the couple’s son, Barron, the book says.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: Melania Trump, the first lady, remained in New York during the first months of her husband’s presidency because she was renegotiating their prenuptial agreement after his surprise victory in the 2016 election, according to a new book.
2020-06-12.headline_main: Book Says Melania Trump Delayed Washington Move as Negotiating Tack

2020-06-12.abstract: A rule finalized on Friday by the Department of Health and Human Services means that the federal government no longer recognizes gender identity as an avenue for sex discrimination in health care.
2020-06-12.snippet: A rule finalized on Friday by the Department of Health and Human Services means that the federal government no longer recognizes gender identity as an avenue for sex discrimination in health care.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Friday finalized a regulation that will erase protections for transgender patients against discrimination by doctors, hospitals and health insurance companies, a move announced on the four-year anniversary of the massacre at a gay nightclub in Orlando and in the middle of Pride Month.
2020-06-12.headline_main: Trump Administration Erases Transgender Civil Rights Protections in Health Care

2020-06-12.abstract: From the documentary works of Anna Deavere Smith to brief monologues written in this moment of unrest, dramatists are sounding an alarm.
2020-06-12.snippet: From the documentary works of Anna Deavere Smith to brief monologues written in this moment of unrest, dramatists are sounding an alarm.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: Violence against black people is nothing new — not in real life and not in the theater. Especially in the last few years, playwrights have been telling the stories, sounding the alarm and predicting our current upheaval. Newer works, too, created under the stress of grief, have been trying to put George Floyd and Ahmaud Arbery and Breonna Taylor and too many others in a larger context.
2020-06-12.headline_main: 12 Streamable Plays That Depict Black Lives Pierced by Racism

2020-06-12.abstract: We thought the U.S. presidential race would be the biggest story of the year. How wrong we were.
2020-06-12.snippet: We thought the U.S. presidential race would be the biggest story of the year. How wrong we were.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: On Thursday’s episode, we spoke with Astead Herndon, a national political reporter, about the logistical meltdown in Georgia’s primary election. Astead was a regular guest on our series The Field, taking us with him on the campaign trail earlier this year. We asked him to reflect on what has changed since his last appearance for that show:
2020-06-12.headline_main: Remember the Election?

2020-06-12.abstract: On June 15 and 16, a tentative welcome mat is being laid out for visitors in many European countries and a few Caribbean islands. In most places, Americans won’t be on the invite list.
2020-06-12.snippet: On June 15 and 16, a tentative welcome mat is being laid out for visitors in many European countries and a few Caribbean islands. In most places, Americans won’t be on the invite list.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: As the world slowly reopens to tourism, June 15 — and, in some cases, June 16 — has emerged as a significant date, especially in Europe, where the European Union plans on lifting many internal borders. Additional waves of reopenings are expected later in the summer, but for now, visitors from the United States aren’t typically on the invite list.
2020-06-12.headline_main: For Much of Europe, Reopening Day Is Here

2020-06-12.abstract: The Christopher Nolan film will open on July 31 instead of July 17, meaning Disney’s “Mulan” will be the first big movie released since the pandemic closed theaters. Unless it also moves.
2020-06-12.snippet: The Christopher Nolan film will open on July 31 instead of July 17, meaning Disney’s “Mulan” will be the first big movie released since the pandemic closed theaters. Unless it also moves.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It’s now on you, “Mulan.”
2020-06-12.headline_main: ‘Tenet,’ Expected to Signal Hollywood’s Return, Is Pushed Back

2020-06-12.abstract: Inquiries in California and Washington are a sign that the scrutiny of the tech giant continues to intensify.
2020-06-12.snippet: Inquiries in California and Washington are a sign that the scrutiny of the tech giant continues to intensify.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — State investigators in California and Washington have been looking into whether Amazon abuses its power over sellers on the tech giant’s site, according to people involved with the inquiry.
2020-06-12.headline_main: Amazon Said to Be Under Scrutiny in 2 States for Abuse of Power

2020-06-12.abstract: Hundreds are staging a tribute to Felix Gonzalez-Torres’s edible sculpture. It addresses the grief of today’s pandemic — just as it did the AIDS crisis.
2020-06-12.snippet: Hundreds are staging a tribute to Felix Gonzalez-Torres’s edible sculpture. It addresses the grief of today’s pandemic — just as it did the AIDS crisis.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: It is a quiet homecoming: a mound of fortune cookies on a Havana rooftop overlooking a wide, green river. Art lovers come in ones and twos, cracking open a cookie to read their fortunes, sometimes popping the treat in their mouths.
2020-06-12.headline_main: A Homecoming of Good Fortune for an Artist’s Pile of Cookies

2020-06-12.abstract: He was applauded for broadening the bureau’s ranks to include more black, Hispanic and female agents. But many of his other actions drew severe criticism.
2020-06-12.snippet: He was applauded for broadening the bureau’s ranks to include more black, Hispanic and female agents. But many of his other actions drew severe criticism.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: William S. Sessions, a director of the F.B.I. under three presidents, from 1987 to 1993, who challenged racial and gender bias in his agency but struggled to redefine its mission in a time of domestic turmoil, and who was fired after being accused of ethical lapses, died on Friday in San Antonio. He was 90.
2020-06-12.headline_main: William S. Sessions, F.B.I. Director at a Turbulent Time, Dies at 90

2020-06-12.abstract: The silverback, known as Rafiki, was killed by a poacher with a spear, according to the Uganda Wildlife Authority. He was the leader of the famed Nkuringo gorilla group, which has been popular with tourists for decades.
2020-06-12.snippet: The silverback, known as Rafiki, was killed by a poacher with a spear, according to the Uganda Wildlife Authority. He was the leader of the famed Nkuringo gorilla group, which has been popular with tourists for decades.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: Four poachers were arrested this week in connection with the killing of a rare silverback gorilla in Uganda’s Bwindi Impenetrable National Park, a lush preserve of mist-shrouded hillsides and thick rain forests that is home to nearly half of the world’s mountain gorillas, the authorities said.
2020-06-12.headline_main: Four Poachers Arrested After Killing of Rare Silverback Gorilla in Uganda

2020-06-12.abstract: The state became one of the first to make major changes in police practices in the wake of George Floyd’s killing, which has spurred nationwide protests.
2020-06-12.snippet: The state became one of the first to make major changes in police practices in the wake of George Floyd’s killing, which has spurred nationwide protests.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: New York on Friday became one of the first states to take meaningful action to restrict police forces after the killing of George Floyd, banning the use of chokeholds by law enforcement and repealing a half-century-old law that has kept police disciplinary records secret in the state.
2020-06-12.headline_main: N.Y. Bans Chokeholds and Approves Other Measures to Restrict Police

2020-06-12.abstract: Deep-rooted inequality and graft have thwarted the steps Peru took to prepare for its response to the pandemic.

2020-06-12.snippet: Some worry that continuing the season would hamper the active role several players have taken in the Black Lives Matter movement.

2020-06-12.abstract: Two workers on the border wall learned they have the virus, prompting fears of further spread. Some residents had urged a halt to construction during the pandemic.
2020-06-12.snippet: Two workers on the border wall learned they have the virus, prompting fears of further spread. Some residents had urged a halt to construction during the pandemic.

2020-06-12.abstract: Because reform won’t happen.
2020-06-12.snippet: Because reform won’t happen.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: Congressional Democrats want to make it easier to identify and prosecute police misconduct; Joe Biden wants to give police departments $300 million. But efforts to solve police violence through liberal reforms like these have failed for nearly a century.
2020-06-12.headline_main: Yes, We Mean Literally Abolish the Police

2020-06-12.abstract: Here are our endorsements in the congressional primaries. In-person voting begins June 13.
2020-06-12.snippet: Here are our endorsements in the congressional primaries. In-person voting begins June 13.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: At a time when millions of voices are calling out for peaceful change, New Yorkers can make an immediate difference with this year’s primary elections. In-person voting begins June 13 and ends June 23; voting by absentee ballot has already begun. The nation badly needs new faces, new energy, new talent and new ideas.
2020-06-12.headline_main: New York Voters Can Send Some Promising New Faces to Congress

2020-06-12.abstract: What if the state could create a new heritage?
2020-06-12.snippet: What if the state could create a new heritage?
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: OXFORD, Miss. — I’m a proud Mississippian, and our state’s poet laureate, but I don’t fly the state flag. Neither do my friends and neighbors, white or black (I’m white). The reason is simple: Mississippi, which has the country’s highest percentage of black residents, is the last state in the nation to have a flag that incorporates the Confederate symbol.
2020-06-12.headline_main: A Flag for All in Mississippi

2020-06-12.abstract: The racism was too much. I fled.
2020-06-12.snippet: The racism was too much. I fled.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: LAMBEAU, Trinidad and Tobago — I watched the video of George Floyd taking his last breaths under the knee of a Minneapolis police officer while scrolling through Facebook early one morning here. The sound of crashing waves and my children’s giggles created the soundtrack for the devastating images.
2020-06-12.headline_main: I’m a Black American. I Had to Get Out.

2020-06-12.abstract: North Korea’s nuclear arsenal is far larger than it was when President Trump and Kim Jong-un of North Korea first met.
2020-06-12.snippet: North Korea’s nuclear arsenal is far larger than it was when President Trump and Kim Jong-un of North Korea first met.
2020-06-12.lead_paragraph: The timing was hardly coincidental when North Korea’s foreign minister declared on Friday that hopes for finding peace with South Korea and its protector, the United States, “faded away into a dark nightmare,” and that talking with President Trump had given way to focusing on a more “reliable force to cope with the long-term military threats from the U.S.”
2020-06-12.headline_main: Two Years After Trump-Kim Meeting, Little to Show for Personal Diplomacy

2020-06-12.abstract: Asbury Park officials voted to flout orders barring restaurants from allowing indoor dining, but backed down under pressure from the governor.
