Mr. Charlson is more than a one-trick pony and today there are some good puns and factoids to explore.

2020-06-13.snippet: On June 19, 1865, enslaved African-Americans in Galveston, Texas, were told they were free. Now, 155 years later, people in cities and towns across the U.S. continue to mark the occasion with celebrations.

2020-06-13.abstract: A family of divorce lawyers navigates their own messy relationships, and NBC airs a special report about the coronavirus pandemic.
2020-06-13.snippet: A family of divorce lawyers navigates their own messy relationships, and NBC airs a special report about the coronavirus pandemic.
2020-06-13.lead_paragraph: THE SPLIT Stream on Sundance Now, Sundance TV, Amazon, Google Play, Hulu, iTunes and YouTube TV. On the first season of this drama, centered around a family of high-powered divorce lawyers, Ruth Defoe (Deborah Findlay), the matriarch, gives a speech at her daughter’s wedding that gets at the heart of the series. “I have found through life that love and hate are so often intertwined,” she says. “Or perhaps, I should say, that the love that’s there at the start is still there at the end.” As Ruth and her daughters Nina (Annabel Scholey) and Hannah (Nicola Walker), both lawyers, help their clients navigate the often heartless legal world of infidelity, prenuptial agreements and divorce, they are forced to come to terms with the emotional challenges in their own relationships. As Margaret Lyons, a television critic for The New York Times, wrote in her Watching column: “If you like ensemble dramas in which smart, elegant people stand in nice kitchens and sadly ponder their lives, watch this.”
2020-06-13.headline_main: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘The Split’ and a ‘Dateline’ Special

2020-06-13.abstract: Christian Streich, the coach of unassuming Freiburg, acts as German soccer’s unofficial social conscience. The Bundesliga’s recent stoppage gave him a chance to reflect on his relationship with his sport.
2020-06-13.snippet: Christian Streich, the coach of unassuming Freiburg, acts as German soccer’s unofficial social conscience. The Bundesliga’s recent stoppage gave him a chance to reflect on his relationship with his sport.
2020-06-13.lead_paragraph: Christian Streich has to go. He is conscious that it is nearing 10 a.m., and training is about to start. His S.C. Freiburg players — he calls them his “colleagues” — will soon be out on the field, wondering where their coach has gone. With a hint of apology, he wonders if we might, perhaps, make these the last couple of questions?
2020-06-13.headline_main: The Teachings of the Philosopher of the Black Forest

2020-06-13.abstract: The president has taken his degradation of the truth to new lengths, but the basic project has been the same from the start.
2020-06-13.snippet: The president has taken his degradation of the truth to new lengths, but the basic project has been the same from the start.
2020-06-13.lead_paragraph: No president in the history of our Republic has been as disorienting as Donald Trump. His goal, even before he became president, was far more ambitious than to tell mere lies. It was to annihilate the distinction between truth and falsity, to make sure that we no longer share facts in common, to overwhelm people with misinformation and disinformation. It was to induce epistemological vertigo on a mass scale.
2020-06-13.headline_main: Trump Has Made Alternative Facts a Way of Life

2020-06-13.lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — Through the thin wall separating her from her neighbors, Dr. Anzhela Kirilova began to hear the rasping cough associated with Covid-19 sometime in May. That was hardly a surprise, as a few weeks earlier her neighbors had heard the same cough coming from her room.

2020-06-13.abstract: There are about a septillion stars in the observable universe. You can bring a fraction into your home — which is more than enough.
2020-06-13.snippet: There are about a septillion stars in the observable universe. You can bring a fraction into your home — which is more than enough.
2020-06-13.lead_paragraph: By now, you’ve spent more than enough time inside, and although you may be trying to get back out into nature, the options are still limited, especially after sunset. If you have a backyard or balcony and a clear moonless night, you might be able to look up and glimpse a few stars. But with the effects of light pollution, if you want to really see the stars — and lots of them — you’ll need to bring them to you.
2020-06-13.headline_main: Stick a Starry Night Sky on Your Ceiling

2020-06-13.abstract: This June has restored the spirit of protest to Pride celebrations. Here are shows to help you understand the moment.
2020-06-13.snippet: This June has restored the spirit of protest to Pride celebrations. Here are shows to help you understand the moment.
2020-06-13.lead_paragraph: This year, Pride has been forced back to its roots. Instead of celebrities waving from floats sponsored by TD Bank and Absolut Vodka, pandemic-masked protesters are marching in the streets demanding justice for black lives. Rainbow flags have been replaced with signs with the names of those killed by the police, like Tony McDade, a black trans man in Tallahassee, Fla. These protests may be perhaps the most genuine honoring of Pride, an annual commemoration of the 1969 Stonewall uprising, in which black and brown L.G.B.T.Q. people were a driving force. There is much to learn this Pride, and a legion of queer voices in podcasting can help you gain insight, find representation and feel comfort during this time. Here are a few of our recommendations.
2020-06-13.headline_main: 5 Podcasts at the Intersection of Pride Month and the Black Lives Matter Movement

2020-06-13.snippet: Millions of dollars were spent to alter overly aggressive policing after the killing of Michael Brown in 2014, with little result. Will George Floyd’s death be different?

But now that the city is reopening, does that mean it’s safe to install them? Will my Manhattan co-op even allow someone to come in and do the work?

2020-06-13.abstract: Smith, whose iconic protest alongside John Carlos at the 1968 Olympics shined a light on racial inequality, talked about today’s protests, Colin Kaepernick and what needs to happen now.
2020-06-13.snippet: Smith, whose iconic protest alongside John Carlos at the 1968 Olympics shined a light on racial inequality, talked about today’s protests, Colin Kaepernick and what needs to happen now.
2020-06-13.lead_paragraph: In 1968, Tommie Smith and John Carlos stepped to the podium at the Olympics in Mexico City to receive their medals in the 200-meter dash. Wearing black socks and no shoes to represent poverty and black gloves to signify black power and liberation, the sprinters raised their fists.

2020-06-14.abstract: Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa revisit the home run record chase of 1998, and the dark detective drama returns to Netflix.
2020-06-14.snippet: Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa revisit the home run record chase of 1998, and the dark detective drama returns to Netflix.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: 30 FOR 30: LONG GONE SUMMER 9 p.m. on ESPN. During the summer of 1998, many sports fans seemed to be captivated by one single story — the chase between the St. Louis Cardinals’ Mark McGwire and the Chicago Cubs’ Sammy Sosa to beat Roger Maris’s record of 61 home runs in a single season. In this documentary, Sosa and McGwire take viewers back to the high-drama slugfest. The film also explores how the revelations of steroid use in the league would later call the accomplishments of the sport — and that season — into question.
2020-06-14.headline_main: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘30 for 30’ and ‘Marcella’

2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: Impromptu concerts from the fire escape. Food relief efforts staged on the sidewalk in front of a church. Friends spread out on the stoop and drinking tallboys. As the city reopens, New Yorkers emerging from quarantine might feel a bit nostalgic for the socially distant bonds they formed outside their homes. From the first days of the lockdown in April, through the advent of legal drinking in front of restaurants, to protests in the streets for racial justice, The Times collected stories of how neighbors across the five boroughs handled the shutdown and, at times, came together.

2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: Chris Wallace is a registered Democrat who hosts “Fox News Sunday,” a child of two Jews who keeps a rosary by his bedside, a Washington wonk who has vacationed in Italy with George Clooney.
2020-06-14.headline_main: Chris Wallace, Insider and Outlier at Fox News

2020-06-14.abstract: Progressive and racial justice groups have seen a cascade of donations since George Floyd’s death and the ensuing protests. Bail funds alone have received $90 million.
2020-06-14.snippet: Progressive and racial justice groups have seen a cascade of donations since George Floyd’s death and the ensuing protests. Bail funds alone have received $90 million.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: The killing of George Floyd and the ensuing nationwide wave of protests are generating a record-setting flood of donations to racial justice groups, bail funds and black-led advocacy organizations across America, remaking the financial landscape of black political activism in a matter of weeks.
2020-06-14.headline_main: Racial Justice Groups Flooded With Millions in Donations in Wake of Floyd Death

2020-06-14.abstract: Boxers wearing surgical booties. Wristbands with bar codes. Meals served behind plexiglass. Our journalists took a look behind the scenes of boxing’s comeback in Las Vegas.
2020-06-14.snippet: Boxers wearing surgical booties. Wristbands with bar codes. Meals served behind plexiglass. Our journalists took a look behind the scenes of boxing’s comeback in Las Vegas.

2020-06-14.abstract: How bad will it be?
2020-06-14.snippet: How bad will it be?
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: After another week of widespread protests and relaxed lockdown rules, coronavirus cases are spiking in over a dozen states. What does that mean for the economy? Catch up on the big stories in business and tech for the week ahead, and stay safe.

2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: With sunny and warm weekend weather in New York City and its suburbs, social media feeds were filled with videos and reports of residents violating social distancing rules, including Friday night in Manhattan’s East Village, a bar-and-restaurant friendly neighborhood. Outdoor drinkers, many without masks, also congregated on street corners in Hell’s Kitchen on Saturday, where gay pride celebrations were underway.
2020-06-14.headline_main: As Social Distancing Wanes, Cuomo Warns of Another Lockdown

2020-06-14.abstract: Fifty years ago, the Alban Berg Quartet was founded. A huge box set, comforting yet daring, is an immersive celebration.
2020-06-14.snippet: Fifty years ago, the Alban Berg Quartet was founded. A huge box set, comforting yet daring, is an immersive celebration.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: Half a century ago, a string quartet formed in Vienna. This might not seem like an especially noteworthy event, given that city’s towering importance in the history of music — and chamber music, in particular. Surely quartets have always been a dime a dozen there.
2020-06-14.headline_main: My Favorite String Quartet

2020-06-14.abstract: When Robert Indiana died, the man who had directed his affairs was supposed to help run the artist’s foundation and its new museum. Those plans have changed.
2020-06-14.snippet: When Robert Indiana died, the man who had directed his affairs was supposed to help run the artist’s foundation and its new museum. Those plans have changed.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: One person was conspicuously absent from an event at the Farnsworth Museum in Rockland, Maine, last year, a gathering as close to a memorial for Robert Indiana as has been held since his death two years ago.
2020-06-14.headline_main: The Artist’s Caretaker: Once He Controlled Everything. No More.

2020-06-14.abstract: Find comfort in lamb biryani, a lentil-orzo stew, or a feta-brined roast chicken.
2020-06-14.snippet: Find comfort in lamb biryani, a lentil-orzo stew, or a feta-brined roast chicken.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: Good morning. Joy is in short supply these days, and patience, too. Nerves are tingling. I haven’t shaken a hand or hugged someone outside my family in more than three months. Cooking’s supposed to be a solace — I say that every day — but I acknowledge that some days it doesn’t seem possible. I do it anyway (gotta eat). I do it anyway (it’s a practice, same as singing scales, same as draining free throws). I do it anyway (I believe).
2020-06-14.headline_main: What to Cook This Week

2020-06-14.abstract: An early 20th-century federal water project irrigated the prairie to create farms and towns in eastern Montana. But it needs a $200 million overhaul.
2020-06-14.snippet: An early 20th-century federal water project irrigated the prairie to create farms and towns in eastern Montana. But it needs a $200 million overhaul.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: CUT BANK, Mont. — A century ago, one of the first of the ambitious federal water projects that helped build the West was constructed to carry water from the mountains of Glacier National Park hundreds of miles east, irrigating an area twice the size of Maryland.
2020-06-14.headline_main: A Canal That Opened the Montana Prairie May Soon Dry Up

2020-06-14.abstract: I understand that the protests are necessary medicine for both the pandemic and our country’s racism.
2020-06-14.snippet: I understand that the protests are necessary medicine for both the pandemic and our country’s racism.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: As a black emergency medicine physician, concern about the spread of Covid-19 at protests in the wake of the murder of George Floyd is not top of my mind. And yet many continue to seize on this concern. The risk of spread of Covid-19 is clearly elevated at demonstrations: People are yelling, stirring up respiratory droplets and projecting them into the air; people are marching long distances, exerting themselves and taking gulps of air in the process; people are standing and kneeling much less than six feet from one another; and mask use is, over all, abundant but admittedly inconsistent.
2020-06-14.headline_main: As a Black Doctor, Should I Choose My Skin Color or My Health?

2020-06-14.abstract: The Psalms are not silent about the rage of the oppressed.
2020-06-14.snippet: The Psalms are not silent about the rage of the oppressed.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: There are videos of Eric Garner and George Floyd being choked to death by police officers while pleading for their lives. There is a video of Tamir Rice, a 12-year-old boy who was shot to death while playing with a toy gun. There is a video of Ahmaud Arbery, who was hunted and killed while out on a run. There is a video of a police officer mounting and handcuffing Dajerria Becton, 15 years old at the time, at a pool party.
2020-06-14.headline_main: What the Bible Has to Say About Black Anger

2020-06-14.abstract: After another black man is shot and killed by police officers, Atlanta erupts in outrage, and discussion swirls around proposals to radically overhaul law enforcement around the country.
2020-06-14.snippet: After another black man is shot and killed by police officers, Atlanta erupts in outrage, and discussion swirls around proposals to radically overhaul law enforcement around the country.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our continuing coverage of Atlanta, Black Lives Matter and police protests here.
2020-06-14.headline_main: Details of Shooting in Atlanta Fuel Debate on Police Use of Force

2020-06-14.abstract: In presidential election years, state driver licensing offices and registration drives generate a torrent of new voters. The pandemic has cut that to a trickle.
2020-06-14.snippet: In presidential election years, state driver licensing offices and registration drives generate a torrent of new voters. The pandemic has cut that to a trickle.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a normal election year, volunteers from the Columbus, Ohio, chapter of the League of Women Voters would have spent last weekend at the Columbus Arts Fair, pens and clipboards in hand, looking to sign up new voters among the festival’s 400,000 or so attendees.
2020-06-14.headline_main: Covid-19 Changed How We Vote. It Could Also Change Who Votes.

2020-06-14.abstract: While Stewart waits for the W.N.B.A. to agree to start the season, she’s been attending protests, lobbying to add “Black Lives Matter” to the league’s courts and listening as much as possible.
2020-06-14.snippet: While Stewart waits for the W.N.B.A. to agree to start the season, she’s been attending protests, lobbying to add “Black Lives Matter” to the league’s courts and listening as much as possible.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: Along with the rest of the world, athletes have had their careers upended by the coronavirus pandemic. They are giving The New York Times an intimate look at their journeys in periodic installments through the rest of the year. Read Stewart’s first installment here.
2020-06-14.headline_main: Breanna Stewart Pushes for Change on and Off the Court

2020-06-14.abstract: Readers describe travel experiences on planes and in airports that left them uneasy and call for more rigorous safety measures.
2020-06-14.snippet: Readers describe travel experiences on planes and in airports that left them uneasy and call for more rigorous safety measures.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
2020-06-14.headline_main: Passengers Still Jittery About Flying

2020-06-14.snippet: A reader suggests “a cabinet-level position devoted to eradicating racism.” Also: The Republican vote this fall; hospital finances in the pandemic.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
2020-06-14.headline_main: How Biden Can Fight Racism

2020-06-14.abstract: When Russian table tennis or Korean baseball won’t scratch the itch, some are trying their hand at trading equities. It’s enough to move the market, analysts say.
2020-06-14.snippet: When Russian table tennis or Korean baseball won’t scratch the itch, some are trying their hand at trading equities. It’s enough to move the market, analysts say.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: When he wasn’t coaching sports, he was playing them or watching them. And if he was watching — well, a little skin in the game always made it more interesting for Steven Young, a teacher outside Philadelphia. Just small-dollar bets, mixed in with shuffling the rosters of his fantasy teams.
2020-06-14.headline_main: Trading Sportsbooks for Brokerages, Bored Bettors Wager on Stocks

2020-06-14.abstract: Afghanistan’s health system, largely dependent on foreign aid, has been overwhelmed, and official numbers are seen as an indication of a widening catastrophe.
2020-06-14.snippet: Afghanistan’s health system, largely dependent on foreign aid, has been overwhelmed, and official numbers are seen as an indication of a widening catastrophe.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Every day, thousands of people swarmed Hakeem Alokozai’s herbal clinic in Kabul seeking their three drops of his Covid-19 “vaccine.” Some carried IV drips, others oxygen cylinders. Some were brought in ambulances, others in the back of Toyota station wagons. They were laborers, officers of the security forces and even lawmakers in the country’s Parliament.
2020-06-14.headline_main: Desperate for Any Coronavirus Care, Afghans Flock to Herbalist’s ‘Vaccine’

2020-06-14.abstract: Bristol was built with money from the slave trader Edward Colston. Tearing down his statue has reopened a painful reckoning with the city’s racist past.
2020-06-14.snippet: Bristol was built with money from the slave trader Edward Colston. Tearing down his statue has reopened a painful reckoning with the city’s racist past.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: BRISTOL, England — Standing beneath an empty stone plinth, from which the statue of the 17th-century slave trader Edward Colston was toppled last week, Richard Saunders showed his son photos of three black Americans who had been killed by the police an ocean away and 200 years after the end of Bristol’s slave trade.
2020-06-14.headline_main: In an English City, an Early Benefactor Is Now ‘a Toxic Brand’

2020-06-14.abstract: Representative Denver Riggleman of Virginia, who was endorsed by President Trump, lost his re-election bid in an unusual drive-through convention to a self-described “biblical conservative.”
2020-06-14.snippet: Representative Denver Riggleman of Virginia, who was endorsed by President Trump, lost his re-election bid in an unusual drive-through convention to a self-described “biblical conservative.”
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Denver Riggleman, a freshman Republican from Virginia, lost a bitterly contested primary race decided in an unusual drive-through state convention, weighed down by outrage among party activists that he officiated at a same-sex wedding.
2020-06-14.headline_main: G.O.P. Congressman Is Ousted From Right After Officiating at Same-Sex Wedding

2020-06-14.abstract: Many mass immunization efforts worldwide were halted this spring to prevent spread of the virus at crowded inoculation sites. The consequences have been alarming.
2020-06-14.snippet: Many mass immunization efforts worldwide were halted this spring to prevent spread of the virus at crowded inoculation sites. The consequences have been alarming.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: As poor countries around the world struggle to beat back the coronavirus, they are unintentionally contributing to fresh explosions of illness and death from other diseases — ones that are readily prevented by vaccines.
2020-06-14.headline_main: Slowing the Coronavirus Is Speeding the Spread of Other Diseases

2020-06-14.abstract: Patients who were treated for the virus are largely supposed to be exempt from receiving large bills. One hospital erroneously sent one.
2020-06-14.snippet: Patients who were treated for the virus are largely supposed to be exempt from receiving large bills. One hospital erroneously sent one.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: Janet Mendez started receiving bills soon after returning in April to her mother’s home from Mount Sinai Morningside hospital, where she nearly died of Covid-19. First, there was one for $31,165. Unable to work and finding it difficult to walk, Ms. Mendez decided to put the bill out of her mind and focus on her recovery.
2020-06-14.headline_main: She Survived the Coronavirus. Then She Got a $400,000 Medical Bill.

2020-06-14.abstract: When a Chinese manufacturer swept in to save the Swedish car marque, it was warmly welcomed. A decade later, plans for a fuller merger are being debated in a frostier atmosphere.
2020-06-14.snippet: When a Chinese manufacturer swept in to save the Swedish car marque, it was warmly welcomed. A decade later, plans for a fuller merger are being debated in a frostier atmosphere.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: GOTHENBURG, Sweden —  The 2009 meeting in Shanghai between the Swedish union leader and the “Chinese Henry Ford” started in a minibus ride and ended in one of the financial capital’s most opulent hotels. There, the men struck an unlikely alliance to save the struggling Swedish carmaker Volvo.
2020-06-14.headline_main: Fears for Volvo Expose Sour Turn in Sweden’s Ties With China

2020-06-14.abstract: The president also appeared to have trouble raising a glass of water to his mouth during a speech at West Point a day before he turned 74, the oldest a president has been in his first term.
2020-06-14.snippet: The president also appeared to have trouble raising a glass of water to his mouth during a speech at West Point a day before he turned 74, the oldest a president has been in his first term.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: President Trump faced new questions about his health on Sunday, after videos emerged of him gingerly walking down a ramp at the U.S. Military Academy at West Point and having trouble bringing a glass of water to his mouth during a speech there.
2020-06-14.headline_main: Trump’s Halting Walk Down Ramp Raises New Health Questions

2020-06-14.abstract: A baseball season of roughly 50 games appears to be increasingly inevitable after another round of pointed statements between the league and the players’ union.
2020-06-14.snippet: A baseball season of roughly 50 games appears to be increasingly inevitable after another round of pointed statements between the league and the players’ union.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: What once seemed like a worst-case scenario for Major League Baseball — a regular season of roughly 50 games — now appears to be all but inevitable.
2020-06-14.headline_main: After More Proposals, Players Tell M.L.B.: ‘Tell Us When and Where’

2020-06-14.abstract: The 1939 blockbuster once symbolized the ultimate in mass entertainment. But African-Americans have protested against it from the start, even if white America didn’t want to hear it.
2020-06-14.snippet: The 1939 blockbuster once symbolized the ultimate in mass entertainment. But African-Americans have protested against it from the start, even if white America didn’t want to hear it.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: When HBO Max announced Tuesday that it was temporarily removing “Gone With the Wind” from its streaming service, it seemed as if another Confederate monument was coming down.
2020-06-14.headline_main: The Long Battle Over ‘Gone With the Wind’

2020-06-14.abstract: Mr. Rajput, who got his start on television in 2008, was “blessed with wonderful screen presence,” one critic said. The police called his death a suicide.
2020-06-14.snippet: Mr. Rajput, who got his start on television in 2008, was “blessed with wonderful screen presence,” one critic said. The police called his death a suicide.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: Sushant Singh Rajput, a prominent actor in Indian films and television programs, was found dead on Sunday in his home in Mumbai. He was 34.

2020-06-14.abstract: I’ve covered Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo for seven years, and thought I understood him well. Then the virus came, and his news conferences started. As they come to an end, here are a few things I learned.
2020-06-14.snippet: I’ve covered Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo for seven years, and thought I understood him well. Then the virus came, and his news conferences started. As they come to an end, here are a few things I learned.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
2020-06-14.headline_main: My Front-Row View of the Cuomo Briefings

2020-06-14.abstract: Social gatherings and campaign rallies like those planned by President Trump could spread infections this summer. People should wear masks and continue social distancing, public health researchers say.
2020-06-14.snippet: Social gatherings and campaign rallies like those planned by President Trump could spread infections this summer. People should wear masks and continue social distancing, public health researchers say.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: The coronavirus won’t be loosening its grip on the United States any time soon, leading infectious disease experts said on Sunday. They are also uncertain how the viral spread will be affected by the patchwork of states reopening businesses and by large events like protests and President Trump’s upcoming campaign rallies.
2020-06-14.headline_main: Events Like Trump Rally Are ‘Perfect Storm’ for Viral Spread, Experts Say

2020-06-14.abstract: The inside story of the Black birder and the white woman who called the police on him. Their encounter stirred wrenching conversations about racism and white privilege.
2020-06-14.snippet: The inside story of the Black birder and the white woman who called the police on him. Their encounter stirred wrenching conversations about racism and white privilege.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: Christian Cooper began his Memorial Day like most of his May mornings, searching for Blackburnian warblers, scarlet tanagers and other songbirds that wing their way into Central Park.
2020-06-14.headline_main: How 2 Lives Collided in Central Park, Rattling the Nation

2020-06-14.abstract: Spike Lee’s movie is filled with references to movies and Vietnam-era events. We explain who’s who and what’s what.
2020-06-14.snippet: Spike Lee’s movie is filled with references to movies and Vietnam-era events. We explain who’s who and what’s what.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: Through their blistering engagement with history, pop culture and headlines, Spike Lee’s movies always brim with references, and “Da 5 Bloods,” his new feature on Netflix, is no exception. The drama follows four Vietnam veterans, “the Bloods” — Paul (Delroy Lindo), Otis (Clarke Peters), Eddie (Norm Lewis) and Melvin (Isiah Whitlock Jr.) — who return to the country with a dual purpose: to recover the remains of their fallen comrade and to retrieve the gold they buried. A critique of U.S. exploitation of African-Americans in war and in general, “Da 5 Bloods” is also an adventure film and a caper movie, filled with callbacks to Lee’s other works. Below is a guide to some of its many allusions and shout-outs.
2020-06-14.headline_main: A Pop-Culture Glossary for ‘Da 5 Bloods’

2020-06-14.abstract: Bree Newsome Bass was arrested after climbing a flagpole at the South Carolina State Capitol. Now, she sees more people moved to act for similar reasons.
2020-06-14.snippet: Bree Newsome Bass was arrested after climbing a flagpole at the South Carolina State Capitol. Now, she sees more people moved to act for similar reasons.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: She knew she would be arrested, but that was the least of her concerns. She had to make it to the top of the flagpole first.
2020-06-14.headline_main: The Woman Who Took Down a Confederate Flag on What Came Next

2020-06-14.abstract: Sure, it’s Monday, but here’s an Olivia Mitra Framke puzzle.
2020-06-14.snippet: Sure, it’s Monday, but here’s an Olivia Mitra Framke puzzle.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Today’s grid marks Olivia Mitra Framke’s Monday debut and her fifth puzzle with us over all. If you’re on a long puzzle streak, you’ve probably solved her excellent Sunday constructions. (Her first Times puzzle was a Sunday that paid homage to 68A, you might remember.) If you’re still working on Mondays, you can try one of her Tuesday puzzles once you’re done here.
2020-06-14.headline_main: Make Better

2020-06-14.abstract: Thousands of demonstrators gathered around the Brooklyn Museum to bring attention to high rates of police violence against black transgender women.
2020-06-14.snippet: Thousands of demonstrators gathered around the Brooklyn Museum to bring attention to high rates of police violence against black transgender women.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: Thousands of demonstrators gathered around the Brooklyn Museum to bring attention to high rates of police violence against black transgender women.

2020-06-14.abstract: The fatal police shooting of Rayshard Brooks in Atlanta has put a spotlight on a number of officer tactics, including the use of stun guns.
2020-06-14.snippet: The fatal police shooting of Rayshard Brooks in Atlanta has put a spotlight on a number of officer tactics, including the use of stun guns.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: The fatal police shooting of Rayshard Brooks, a black man who was found asleep in a car in a drive-through at a Wendy’s on Friday night in Atlanta, has reignited the debate over Tasers.
2020-06-14.headline_main: Tasers: Are These Police Tools Effective and Are They Dangerous?

2020-06-14.abstract: The former defense secretary became the most senior previous military leader in recent days to endorse renaming 10 Army installations that bear the names of Confederate generals.
2020-06-14.snippet: The former defense secretary became the most senior previous military leader in recent days to endorse renaming 10 Army installations that bear the names of Confederate generals.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: Former Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates joined the call on Sunday to rename Army bases named after Confederate generals despite President Trump’s opposition, saying that it was time to rid the American military of symbols that represent “the dark side of our history.”
2020-06-14.headline_main: Robert Gates Calls to Replace Base Names From ‘Dark Side of Our History’

2020-06-14.abstract: “I can’t be silent anymore.”
2020-06-14.snippet: “I can’t be silent anymore.”
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Running newsletter! Every Saturday morning, we email runners with news, advice and some motivation to help you get up and running. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.
2020-06-14.headline_main: A Conversation With the Ultrarunner Yassine Diboun

2020-06-14.abstract: Bush survived the Iraq war. Trump has mishandled the coronavirus and the protests, but Americans care more about plans going forward.
2020-06-14.snippet: Bush survived the Iraq war. Trump has mishandled the coronavirus and the protests, but Americans care more about plans going forward.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: We know that a bad economy tends to hurt the electoral prospects of incumbent presidential candidates. But what about a crisis of national security or American safety? Although the coronavirus pandemic is unprecedented in most ways, as is the Trump presidency itself, there may be historical lessons from other situations.
2020-06-14.headline_main: Joe Biden Needs to Learn an Urgent Lesson From the 2004 Election

2020-06-14.abstract: The Golden State is less exceptional and more like the rest of America than many would prefer to believe.
2020-06-14.snippet: The Golden State is less exceptional and more like the rest of America than many would prefer to believe.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: PASADENA — California, the novelist Wallace Stegner wrote, is like the rest of America, only more so. That truism has played out in recent days in scenes of triumph, anguish and incongruity, a mirror of the country seen through a distinctly California lens.
2020-06-14.headline_main: The Pandemic and Protests Have Exposed the Truth About California

2020-06-14.abstract: The bodies of Robert Fuller and Malcolm Harsch were found in California, 10 days and 50 miles apart. Their families are demanding deeper investigations.
2020-06-14.snippet: The bodies of Robert Fuller and Malcolm Harsch were found in California, 10 days and 50 miles apart. Their families are demanding deeper investigations.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: The families of two black men who were found hanged from trees in Southern California are asking the authorities to further investigate their deaths.
2020-06-14.headline_main: Families Challenge Suicide in Deaths of Black Men Found Hanging From Trees

2020-06-14.abstract: The author of “If I Had Your Face,” discusses her debut novel — a story of four women pursuing dreams and ambitions in fiercely competitive Seoul.
2020-06-14.snippet: The author of “If I Had Your Face,” discusses her debut novel — a story of four women pursuing dreams and ambitions in fiercely competitive Seoul.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: — Frances Cha, author of “If I Had Your Face”
2020-06-14.headline_main: Author Frances Cha on Achieving the Feminine Ideal

2020-06-14.abstract: It is an everyday struggle to neither fall into despair nor explode in anger.
2020-06-14.snippet: It is an everyday struggle to neither fall into despair nor explode in anger.
2020-06-14.lead_paragraph: In the wake of the killing of George Floyd and the massive wave of protests that have swept the country and the world, New York State on Friday passed a package of policing reforms, banning chokeholds and opening police disciplinary records, among other things.

Putin of Russia on Sunday described the United States as a country gripped by a “deep internal crisis” and attributed it to what he said was a refusal by opponents of President Trump to accept his “obvious” 2016 election victory and his legitimacy as leader.

2020-06-15.abstract: The continuing deaths of black people by the police are undermining support for the wide latitude officers are given in cases in which an encounter ends in a death.
2020-06-15.snippet: The continuing deaths of black people by the police are undermining support for the wide latitude officers are given in cases in which an encounter ends in a death.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The swift decision on Sunday to fire the white Atlanta police officer who shot and killed a black motorist intensified the growing re-examination of the use of deadly force by the police, challenging longstanding principles that have given law enforcement officers wide latitude in cases in which an encounter ends with a death.
2020-06-15.headline_main: Police Killings Prompt Reassessment of Laws Allowing Deadly Force

2020-06-15.abstract: Those who can afford it left the city, shining a spotlight on class divisions in the media.
2020-06-15.snippet: Those who can afford it left the city, shining a spotlight on class divisions in the media.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — Real estate out here is too expensive for a working person, so the East Hampton Golf Club usually provides shared houses for its caddies. But Covid-19 means no boardinghouses, and no boarding means no caddies, and no caddies means that the media moguls who pay more than $400,000 to join (putting it in the middle range for initiation fees in the Hamptons) now must pull their own clubs around, which they’ve been telling one another reminds them of their youth, and which is just the kind of sacrifice that the coronavirus has brought to East Hampton.
2020-06-15.headline_main: Newsrooms Are in Revolt. The Bosses Are in Their Country Houses.

2020-06-15.abstract: A behind-the-scenes documentary by D.A. Pennebaker drops on the Criterion Channel. And Usher closes out the second season of a songwriting competition show.
2020-06-15.snippet: A behind-the-scenes documentary by D.A. Pennebaker drops on the Criterion Channel. And Usher closes out the second season of a songwriting competition show.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: ORIGINAL CAST ALBUM: COMPANY (1970) Stream on the Criterion Channel. Stephen Sondheim’s formally adventurous 1970 Broadway musical about modern relationship issues is viewed by many as his breakout work as an independent creative force. D.A. Pennebaker, the filmmaker known for his documentary work on the upheaval and music of the 1960s and ’70s, was on hand when the original cast gathered at “The Church,” a Columbia Records studio in Midtown Manhattan, to record the show’s cast album. Sondheim is featured in the documentary, as is Elaine Stritch, who played Joanne, and other performers. Among the songs captured are “Another Hundred People” and “The Ladies Who Lunch.”
2020-06-15.headline_main: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Original Cast Album: Company’ and ‘Songland’

2020-06-15.abstract: Efforts to block research on climate change don’t just come from the Trump political appointees on top. Lower managers in government are taking their cues, and running with them.
2020-06-15.snippet: Efforts to block research on climate change don’t just come from the Trump political appointees on top. Lower managers in government are taking their cues, and running with them.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Efforts to undermine climate change science in the federal government, once orchestrated largely by President Trump’s political appointees, are now increasingly driven by midlevel managers trying to protect their jobs and budgets and wary of the scrutiny of senior officials, according to interviews and newly revealed reports and surveys.
2020-06-15.headline_main: A War Against Climate Science, Waged by Washington’s Rank and File

2020-06-15.abstract: Poultry plants continue to run processing lines at a breakneck speed, making it impossible for workers to social distance.
2020-06-15.snippet: Poultry plants continue to run processing lines at a breakneck speed, making it impossible for workers to social distance.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: You’re a worker at a Tyson Foods poultry plant and still punching in even though the coronavirus continues to run rampant through meat-processing plants across the country. You’re proud that your job helps keep supermarkets stocked. Your family supports Donald Trump. But the president’s executive order to keep meat plants open — issued after the Tyson Foods chairman, John Tyson, publicly warned of supply shortages — worries you. You think company leadership pushed for plants to stay open and to run at top speed instead of doing more to keep workers safe. This is the reality for Jerald Brooks, a Tyson poultry processing plant worker in Glen Allen, Va. He is not alone.
2020-06-15.headline_main: We’re Feeding America, but We’re Sacrificing Ourselves

2020-06-15.abstract: The intensifying rift between the military and the president demands attention.
2020-06-15.snippet: The intensifying rift between the military and the president demands attention.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: The first time I saw President Trump referred to as “Cadet Bone Spurs” I laughed, the second time I smiled and the third time I cringed. It’s an apt slur, but it lumps him together with all the other politicians whose military huzzahs contradict their personal histories and whose insult to our men and women in uniform can be reduced to dodging the draft.
2020-06-15.headline_main: The Court-Martial of Donald J. Trump

2020-06-15.abstract: The drop in the headline unemployment number could be offering false hope.
2020-06-15.snippet: The drop in the headline unemployment number could be offering false hope.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: The recent jobs report for May seemed to bring good news: more jobs and lower unemployment. But the coronavirus pandemic has broken most economic charts and models, and all the numbers we regularly watch need a closer look. The decline in unemployment was actually driven by a drop in temporary layoffs. Strip those out, and what remains — let’s call it the core unemployment rate — rose in May.
2020-06-15.headline_main: Don’t Cheer Too Soon. Keep an Eye on the Core Jobless Rate.

2020-06-15.abstract: In less than a week, six Nashville teenagers created a march that drew 10,000 peaceful protesters and gave hope to a whole city.
2020-06-15.snippet: In less than a week, six Nashville teenagers created a march that drew 10,000 peaceful protesters and gave hope to a whole city.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — In real life, Nya Collins, Jade Fuller, Kennedy Green, Emma Rose Smith, Mikayla Smith and Zee Thomas had never met as a group when they came together on Twitter to organize a youth march against police violence. It was unseasonably hot, even for Middle Tennessee, with rain predicted, and earlier protests here had ended in violence, with the Metro Nashville Courthouse and City Hall in flames. Collectively, these are not the most promising conditions for gathering a big crowd, much less a calm one. But the teenagers were determined to press on, even if hardly anyone showed up.
2020-06-15.headline_main: These Kids Are Done Waiting for Change

2020-06-15.abstract: Safety plans border on delusional and could lead to outbreaks of Covid-19 among students, faculty and staff.
2020-06-15.snippet: Safety plans border on delusional and could lead to outbreaks of Covid-19 among students, faculty and staff.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: A number of American colleges and universities have decided to bring students back to campus this fall, believing they can diminish the risk of coronavirus transmission if everyone wears masks, uses hand sanitizer and social distances. Some schools also plan to reconfigure dorms to create family-sized clusters of uninfected students, who could socialize in relative safety, if only with their suite mates.
2020-06-15.headline_main: Expecting Students to Play It Safe if Colleges Reopen Is a Fantasy

2020-06-15.abstract: The tradeoff: full federal funding for expanded Medicaid and unemployment aid, while states fund early childhood programs and infrastructure.
2020-06-15.snippet: The tradeoff: full federal funding for expanded Medicaid and unemployment aid, while states fund early childhood programs and infrastructure.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: Covid-19’s economic devastation has revealed gaping holes in our safety net, as decades-old structures for Medicaid and unemployment insurance are compounding the pain caused by disease and job loss. Let’s be honest, we would not today design them as they were created. The CARES Act took steps to fix these programs, but they need permanent institutional reform and modernization.
2020-06-15.headline_main: A Deal to Save Medicaid, the Unemployed and State Budgets

2020-06-15.abstract: There are thousands of abandoned hamlets in the U.S. Some people still live and vacation in them. Maybe you want to, too?
2020-06-15.snippet: There are thousands of abandoned hamlets in the U.S. Some people still live and vacation in them. Maybe you want to, too?
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: There are some 3,800 ghost towns in the United States, most abandoned in the 19th and early 20th centuries in favor of bigger cities, or casualties of changing industry. Some languish as ruins, others are designated as national parks. And a rare handful are in the midst of being developed into luxury vacation spots.
2020-06-15.headline_main: They Live Alone in Ghost Towns

2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Charter schools, including some with healthy cash balances and billionaire backers like Michael Bloomberg and Bill Gates, have quietly accepted millions of dollars in emergency coronavirus relief from a fund created to help struggling small businesses stay afloat.

2020-06-15.abstract: A new study suggests the interloper may have arisen in an interstellar cloud, where stars are sometimes born.
2020-06-15.snippet: A new study suggests the interloper may have arisen in an interstellar cloud, where stars are sometimes born.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: It has been two and a half years since astronomers in Hawaii discovered a strange, cigar-shaped object speeding through the solar system on a trajectory from far away and toward even farther away. Today Oumuamua, the Hawaiian term for “scout,” as the object was named, is now long gone, somewhere between the orbits of Saturn and Neptune and on its way to the Great Out There, but astronomers are still wondering and debating what it was.
2020-06-15.headline_main: Oumuamua: Neither Comet nor Asteroid, but a Cosmic Iceberg

2020-06-15.abstract: An oral history of the 2015 show, which resulted in death threats to Kerby Jean-Raymond, but solidified him as a powerful new voice in fashion.
2020-06-15.snippet: An oral history of the 2015 show, which resulted in death threats to Kerby Jean-Raymond, but solidified him as a powerful new voice in fashion.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: In the last two years, Kerby Jean-Raymond, the founder of Pyer Moss, has become something of a New York Fashion Week star, famous for taking the African-American experience and putting it front and center on the runway, using such inspiration figures as the black cowboy and Sister Rosetta Tharpe. He has won the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund award, become artistic director of Reebok Studies__ and collaborated with Hennessy.
2020-06-15.headline_main: When Pyer Moss Brought Police Brutality to the Runway

2020-06-15.abstract: Disease experts said limited bursts of infections were likely to become part of the “new normal” for China.

Over the last two weeks, that’s meant that the music business, long a site of racial inequity, has been the subject of a reckoning. In 1890, it was moved to a new lot, now within walking distance of downtown Napa. In the late 1940s, the house was subdivided into apartments. The current owner, who bought it in 2015, turned it back into a single-family house and did an extensive renovation to restore its original splendor, using raw materials sourced from the house.

2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: The world of artificial satellites, silent in the void of space, might seem pacific. In fact it’s a high-flying battlefield rife with jamming, snooping, blinding, spoofing, hacking and hostility among the planet’s growing array of spacecraft and space powers. Now, Chinese scientists report new progress in building what appears to be the first unbreakable information link between an orbiting craft and its terrestrial controllers, raising the odds that Beijing may one day possess a super-secure global communications network.
2020-06-15.headline_main: China Reports Progress in Ultra-Secure Satellite Transmission

2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: Ralph Caplan was the E.B. White of design writing. He disliked windy sentences and pompous clichés and was always ready to poke fun at orthodoxies. He said he wasn’t sure he saw the point of a chair, since human beings could sit on pretty much anything except a cactus.

2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: When the instructor asked him to describe his life in two words, Walter Enriquez chose carefully: fear and violence. He had spent decades as a policeman in Peru during the bloodiest days of armed conflict between government forces and guerrilla fighters that killed nearly 70,000 people. But he said that nothing could have prepared him for the extreme isolation and loneliness that come with quarantine. Having lost a handful of his friends and neighbors to the coronavirus pandemic, the 75-year-old retiree has turned toward art therapy programs offered by the Queens Museum to improve his mental health.
2020-06-15.headline_main: Museums Embrace Art Therapy Techniques for Unsettled Times

2020-06-15.abstract: “Horrible Histories” was meant to be in the West End next month. It’s still happening, just in a castle parking lot 200 miles away.

2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: NETHER WHITACRE, England — Last Tuesday, Morgan Philpott and Neal Foster of the Birmingham Stage Company were in the middle of rehearsing the latest “Horrible Histories” show: a highly successful family theater series in Britain where the country’s past is explained with the aid of fart jokes.
2020-06-15.headline_main: The Only West End Show Still Standing

2020-06-15.abstract: Differences in access to medical care and treatment contribute to conditions that disproportionately hurt minority children.
2020-06-15.snippet: Differences in access to medical care and treatment contribute to conditions that disproportionately hurt minority children.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: You might not have noticed it (there’s a lot going on) but there was some good news last week in a study in JAMA that suggested that racial disparities in extremely premature infants were shrinking. The study looked at more than 20,000 extremely preterm infants (22 to 27 weeks gestation) born from 2002 to 2016. Mortality rates dropped over the course of the study, and though serious infections were more frequent in black and Hispanic infants early on, the rates converged with those of white infants as time went on.
2020-06-15.headline_main: The Impact of Disparities on Children’s Health

2020-06-15.abstract: The Supreme Court’s surprising 6-to-3 ruling in favor of gay and transgender rights was perhaps the strongest evidence yet of how fundamentally and unpredictably American views have changed.
2020-06-15.snippet: The Supreme Court’s surprising 6-to-3 ruling in favor of gay and transgender rights was perhaps the strongest evidence yet of how fundamentally and unpredictably American views have changed.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump was elected president, gay and lesbian leaders warned that their far-reaching victories under Barack Obama — including the Supreme Court’s decision legalizing same-sex marriage in 2015 — were in peril, endangered by the imminent arrival of scores of conservative judges and full Republican control of the federal government.
2020-06-15.headline_main: A Half-Century On, an Unexpected Milestone for L.G.B.T.Q. Rights

2020-06-15.abstract: What city leaders, museum officials and historians decide will have implications for how we remember the history the statues were designed to represent, as well as our current moment.
2020-06-15.snippet: What city leaders, museum officials and historians decide will have implications for how we remember the history the statues were designed to represent, as well as our current moment.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: Guido Gryseels has been getting calls for a week, asking if he’d give some statues a new home. He’s the director of the Africa Museum in Tervuren, Belgium, and his institution, originally founded by Leopold II, might seem like a logical place to house monuments to the 19th-century king whose reign in Congo saw the murder and mutilation of at least 10 million Africans.
2020-06-15.headline_main: The Statues Were Toppled. What Happens to Them Now?

2020-06-15.abstract: Gov. Cuomo warned that lax adherence to social-distancing rules meant to contain the coronavirus could lead him to slow New York City’s reopening.
2020-06-15.snippet: Gov. Cuomo warned that lax adherence to social-distancing rules meant to contain the coronavirus could lead him to slow New York City’s reopening.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: The critical indicators surrounding the coronavirus crisis in New York have clearly turned a corner: Deaths have slowed to a trickle, new cases have declined sharply and the numbers of hospitalizations and intubations have eased.
2020-06-15.headline_main: New Yorkers Flattened the Curve. Now They’re Dropping Their Guard.

2020-06-15.abstract: About 170 small airports around the country get federal subsidies, and far fewer of their flights were disrupted in the pandemic.
2020-06-15.snippet: About 170 small airports around the country get federal subsidies, and far fewer of their flights were disrupted in the pandemic.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: As commercial air travel plummeted in recent months amid pandemic lockdowns and closings, the few people who did venture forth faced delays, cancellations and confusing social distancing messages.
2020-06-15.headline_main: Air Service Was Deeply Cut, but Not to Places Like Lake Placid

2020-06-15.abstract: Add herbs and some alliums to a stick of butter for a lot of flavor.
2020-06-15.snippet: Add herbs and some alliums to a stick of butter for a lot of flavor.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: The term “compound butter” doesn’t sound very delicious. If you weren’t already familiar with its creamy, herb-speckled joys, you might decide to give it a pass.
2020-06-15.headline_main: Make a Compound Butter, and Use It on Your Next Meal

2020-06-15.abstract: The commissioner is reassigning about 600 officers from teams that target violent crime. He called it a “seismic shift” in police culture.
2020-06-15.snippet: The commissioner is reassigning about 600 officers from teams that target violent crime. He called it a “seismic shift” in police culture.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: The New York police commissioner announced on Monday that he was disbanding the Police Department’s anti-crime units: plainclothes teams that target violent crime and have been involved in some of the city’s most notorious police shootings.

2020-06-15.abstract: The acronym, which stands for black, Indigenous and people of color, is suddenly everywhere. Is it doing its job?
2020-06-15.snippet: The acronym, which stands for black, Indigenous and people of color, is suddenly everywhere. Is it doing its job?
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: Black Americans have been called by many names in the United States. African-American, Negro, colored and the unutterable slur that rhymes with bigger. In recent weeks, as protests against police brutality and racism have flooded the streets and social media, another more inclusive term has been ascribed to the population: BIPOC.
2020-06-15.headline_main: Where Did BIPOC Come From?

2020-06-15.abstract: The deal between Fianna Fail and Fine Gael attests to the diminished stature of Ireland’s traditional parties as its political landscape fractures and as support for Sinn Fein grows.
2020-06-15.snippet: The deal between Fianna Fail and Fine Gael attests to the diminished stature of Ireland’s traditional parties as its political landscape fractures and as support for Sinn Fein grows.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Four months after an election that brought down its government but settled little else, Ireland’s two main parties struck an agreement Monday to govern together for the first time, opening an unpredictable chapter in Irish politics as the country faces the economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic.
2020-06-15.headline_main: Ireland’s 2 Main Parties to Jointly Govern for First Time

2020-06-15.abstract: Mr. Engel, a longtime New York representative, is trying to fend off a serious challenge from his left by Jamaal Bowman, who has been endorsed by Bernie Sanders and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez.
2020-06-15.snippet: Mr. Engel, a longtime New York representative, is trying to fend off a serious challenge from his left by Jamaal Bowman, who has been endorsed by Bernie Sanders and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton delivered her first Democratic primary endorsement in a 2020 House race on Monday, throwing her support behind Representative Eliot L. Engel of New York, who is trying to fend off a serious challenge from his left after more than three decades in Congress.
2020-06-15.headline_main: Hillary Clinton Backs Eliot Engel, in Her First House Primary Endorsement of 2020

2020-06-15.abstract: The attorney general there said her office needed more information about $39 million in transactions involving a small bank set up by Jeffrey Epstein.
2020-06-15.snippet: The attorney general there said her office needed more information about $39 million in transactions involving a small bank set up by Jeffrey Epstein.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: A top law enforcement official in the U.S. Virgin Islands contends a small bank set up there by the convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein engaged in a series of unexplained transactions involving tens of millions of dollars before and after his death.

2020-06-15.abstract: Ms. Salau, 19, was found dead along with a 75-year-old woman in Tallahassee, Fla., the police said. A suspect in their deaths has been charged with murder and kidnapping.
2020-06-15.snippet: Ms. Salau, 19, was found dead along with a 75-year-old woman in Tallahassee, Fla., the police said. A suspect in their deaths has been charged with murder and kidnapping.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: A 19-year-old Black Lives Matter activist whose disappearance this month led to a desperate search after she sent a series of tweets describing a sexual assault has been found dead in Tallahassee, Fla., the police said Monday.

2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The head of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration violated the agency’s code of ethics in the fall when he rebuked employees for contradicting President Trump’s inaccurate claim that a hurricane would hit Alabama, NOAA said Monday in a report.
2020-06-15.headline_main: NOAA Chief Violated Ethics Code in Furor Over Trump Tweet, Agency Says

2020-06-15.abstract: The police commissioner said the timing had nothing to do with the prosecutors’ decisions to drop charges against certain protesters, but it seemed to reflect a growing divide.
2020-06-15.snippet: The police commissioner said the timing had nothing to do with the prosecutors’ decisions to drop charges against certain protesters, but it seemed to reflect a growing divide.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: A few hours after the Manhattan district attorney announced he would not prosecute some of the protesters who had been arrested during demonstrations against police brutality, the Police Department sent him a message: All the officers assigned to his office would be pulled off the job to help with crowd control.
2020-06-15.headline_main: After Rift Over Protests, N.Y.P.D. Pulls Out of Prosecutors’ Offices

2020-06-15.abstract: “Toques in Black,” by the food photographer Battman, features the dishes and stories of more than a hundred African-American chefs.
2020-06-15.snippet: “Toques in Black,” by the food photographer Battman, features the dishes and stories of more than a hundred African-American chefs.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: Alan Batt, the food photographer known as Battman, traveled around the country interviewing and photographing black chefs for his latest volume, “Toques in Black.” The book profiles 101 chefs, including the legendary Leah Chase of New Orleans, who died last year. Among the others are Adrienne Cheatham of SundayBest pop-up dinners in Harlem, with uni spoonbread and buttermilk dashi; Digby Stridiron from Braata on St. Croix in the U.S. Virgin Islands offering shrimp escabeche; and JJ Johnson of FieldTrip in New York with whole fried peanut-crusted snapper. Marcus Samuelsson wrote the foreword.
2020-06-15.headline_main: This Photography Book Celebrates Black Chefs

2020-06-15.abstract: The attorney general of California, Xavier Becerra, also said he was sending investigators to Palmdale, Calif., to look into the death of Robert Fuller, a young black man found hanged from a tree near City Hall.
2020-06-15.snippet: The attorney general of California, Xavier Becerra, also said he was sending investigators to Palmdale, Calif., to look into the death of Robert Fuller, a young black man found hanged from a tree near City Hall.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: The attorney general of California, Xavier Becerra, also said he was sending investigators to Palmdale, Calif., to look into the death of Robert Fuller, a young black man found hanged from a tree near City Hall.

2020-06-15.abstract: The rocker’s wine is featured in a new picnic to-go from the rooftop bar Versa in Midtown.
2020-06-15.snippet: The rocker’s wine is featured in a new picnic to-go from the rooftop bar Versa in Midtown.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: Picnicking is an easy socially distant gathering for lunch or dinner. Versa, a rooftop bar and restaurant atop the Renaissance New York Midtown hotel, has assembled picnic baskets that can be ordered for delivery on Saturdays or Sundays to eight Manhattan parks, including Bryant Park, the Sheep Meadow and the Mall in Central Park and Hudson River Park. The basic $35 menu consists of a lobster roll from the Lobster Place in Chelsea Market, a bottle of Evian, a face mask and a bottle of Hampton Water, a pale, floral French rosé developed by Jesse Bongiovi and his father, Jon Bon Jovi, in partnership with the winemaker Gérard Bertrand. For $85, you also get an antipasto platter of charcuterie, cheeses, fruit, flatbread and smoked salmon, and some hand sanitizer. At $135, there are two lobster rolls and two bottles of wine and water, a tote bag and a picnic blanket, along with the other items. Versa and Hampton Water are donating to Black Lives Matter and other charities. Delivery is included. Orders must be placed by 5 p.m. Fridays.
2020-06-15.headline_main: Picnic With Jon Bon Jovi

2020-06-15.abstract: Six former employees of the site sent threatening messages and deliveries to a couple after the e-commerce newsletter they published wrote about a lawsuit involving eBay.
2020-06-15.snippet: Six former employees of the site sent threatening messages and deliveries to a couple after the e-commerce newsletter they published wrote about a lawsuit involving eBay.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: BOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Six eBay employees mounted a cyberstalking campaign — including sending boxes of live cockroaches and a Halloween mask of a bloody pig’s face — against a couple who ran an online e-commerce newsletter, according to charges filed by federal prosecutors on Monday.
2020-06-15.headline_main: Ex-eBay Workers Sent Critics Live Roaches and a Mask of a Bloody Pig Face, U.S. Says

2020-06-15.abstract: Drizzle this honey, from a South Carolina hot sauce maker, over chicken or pizza for a bit of heat.
2020-06-15.snippet: Drizzle this honey, from a South Carolina hot sauce maker, over chicken or pizza for a bit of heat.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: Red Clay, a company in Charleston, S.C., specializes in hot sauces, and just a trace of their new honey will elevate chicken — preferably fried, though grilled or roasted will do — with a touch of mellowness that has subtle bite. There’s more upfront heat, along with a vegetal note, in the company’s Barrel Aged Hot-Hot Honey. Geoff Rhyne, a chef who is also the company’s hot sauce alchemist, uses the leftover habanero pepper mash from making his hot sauces (like the Carolina-style bolstered with vinegar, and a rich verde variety) to season the honeys.
2020-06-15.headline_main: A Hot Honey to Elevate Your Meal

2020-06-15.abstract: The museum will also hold public programs to examine Avery Brundage’s legacy, as well as questions around restitution, and work on “decolonizing’’ the museum.
2020-06-15.snippet: The museum will also hold public programs to examine Avery Brundage’s legacy, as well as questions around restitution, and work on “decolonizing’’ the museum.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For 48 years, visitors to this city’s Asian Art Museum have had to pass the bust of Avery Brundage, its towering patron, an industrialist and former president of the International Olympic Committee. The museum, a jeweled attraction at Civic Center Plaza, was established in 1966 to house his nearly 8,000 art pieces.
2020-06-15.headline_main: Asian Art Museum to Remove Bust of Patron. That’s Just a Start.

2020-06-15.abstract: He was behind Tina Turner’s “Better Be Good to Me” and hits by the Fixx and Howard Jones. He also made a dozen albums of his own songs.
2020-06-15.snippet: He was behind Tina Turner’s “Better Be Good to Me” and hits by the Fixx and Howard Jones. He also made a dozen albums of his own songs.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: Rupert Hine, a prolific English producer and songwriter who thrived in the synth-pop heyday of the 1980s making hits with Tina Turner, the Fixx and Howard Jones, died on June 4 at his home in Wiltshire, England. He was 72.
2020-06-15.headline_main: Rupert Hine, Synth-Pop Music Producer, Dies at 72

2020-06-15.abstract: Why are investors rushing to buy junk?
2020-06-15.snippet: Why are investors rushing to buy junk?
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: After all these years, Hertz is No. 1 again. Not in market share: The car-rental company is a distant second to Enterprise. But Hertz has become Exhibit #1 of the madness that has been sweeping the stock market in these times of Covid-19 — a madness that may do considerable harm, not because stock prices themselves matter all that much, but because Donald Trump and his minions treat the stock market as a measure of their success.
2020-06-15.headline_main: Market Madness in the Pandemic

2020-06-15.abstract: The Museum of Food and Drink has added a BLM Community Resources page to its website, along with a preview of its new “African/American” exhibition.
2020-06-15.snippet: The Museum of Food and Drink has added a BLM Community Resources page to its website, along with a preview of its new “African/American” exhibition.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: BLM Community Resources, on the website for the Museum of Food and Drink, lists scores of black-owned farms, restaurants, food resources in black communities and charities. Among them are a flower farm that Walker Marsh developed on what was an empty lot in Baltimore, and a fund-raiser for the family of David McAtee, the barbecue chef who was shot and killed this month in Louisville, Ky. The museum is asking for public opinion as the webpage evolves. The website also has a preview of “African/American: Making the Nation’s Table,” an exhibition that has been postponed.
2020-06-15.headline_main: Ways to Support Black Farmers, Restaurants and Nonprofits

2020-06-15.abstract: This brass trivet from the Glass House in Connecticut is a good fit for the dinner table.
2020-06-15.snippet: This brass trivet from the Glass House in Connecticut is a good fit for the dinner table.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: An unusual brass wine coaster just landed in the gift shop at the Glass House, the Philip Johnson residence in New Canaan, Conn., that’s now a museum. It has a bulge in the middle to fit the punt, or depression, at the bottom of most wine bottles, making it look, ever so slightly, like the sculpture of a fried egg. Eventual scratches are said to be part of its charm. It was created by Claesson Koivisto Rune, a Swedish design group, for Skultuna 1607.
2020-06-15.headline_main: A Platform for Your Wine Bottle

2020-06-15.abstract: Charged with “inciting debauchery,” Sarah Hegazi was jailed and tortured.
2020-06-15.snippet: Charged with “inciting debauchery,” Sarah Hegazi was jailed and tortured.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — When the openly gay frontman of a hugely popular Lebanese pop group strutted onto the stage of a Cairo summer festival in 2017, rainbow flags lifted in the air, and something sparked inside Sarah Hegazi.
2020-06-15.headline_main: Arrested for Waving Rainbow Flag, a Gay Egyptian Takes Her Life

2020-06-15.abstract: An online auction offers martini glasses from Bar Hemingway, along with a history of the Parisian hotel.
2020-06-15.snippet: An online auction offers martini glasses from Bar Hemingway, along with a history of the Parisian hotel.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: Would you like to own a set of six crystal Bar Hemingway martini glasses from the Ritz in Paris? At an auction from Sunday through Tuesday of tableware and other artifacts from the hotel, there are four lots of these, estimated at 400 to 600 euros (around $450 to $680). Or if your dining area lacks a silver-trimmed tableside gueridon from which to serve the pepperoni pie just delivered from the local pizzeria, there are those, too. The auction is live and online; the digital catalog of nearly 1,500 lots provides the window-shopping, along with a history of the hotel.
2020-06-15.headline_main: Own a Piece of the Ritz

2020-06-15.abstract: The poet Claudia Rankine writes for the Book Review about the climate in America at this moment.
2020-06-15.snippet: The poet Claudia Rankine writes for the Book Review about the climate in America at this moment.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: This week, the Book Review asked two prominent American poets to write original poems responding to this historic moment in our country. Claudia Rankine, whose poem “Weather” appears here and on the front cover of the June 21 issue, is the author of “Citizen: An American Lyric” and other collections, as well as two plays and various essays. She teaches at Yale. Her new book, “Just Us: An American Conversation,” will be published in September. Jericho Brown’s third volume of poetry, “The Tradition,” won the 2020 Pulitzer Prize for poetry. His poem “Say Thank You Say I’m Sorry” appears on the back page of the issue.
2020-06-15.headline_main: ‘Weather’

2020-06-15.abstract: The Pulitzer Prize-winning poet Jericho Brown writes for the Book Review about life during the pandemic.
2020-06-15.snippet: The Pulitzer Prize-winning poet Jericho Brown writes for the Book Review about life during the pandemic.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: This week, the Book Review asked two prominent American poets to write original poems responding to this historic moment in our country. Claudia Rankine, whose poem “Weather” appears on the front cover of the June 21 issue, is the author of “Citizen: An American Lyric” and other collections, as well as two plays and various essays. She teaches at Yale. Her new book, “Just Us: An American Conversation,” will be published in September. Jericho Brown’s third volume of poetry, “The Tradition,” won the 2020 Pulitzer Prize for poetry. His poem “Say Thank You Say I’m Sorry” appears here and on the back page of the issue.
2020-06-15.headline_main: ‘Say Thank You Say I’m Sorry’

2020-06-15.abstract: Golfers went from carping about swab testing to nearly forgetting about social distancing between the ropes, proving a sports truism: Athletes adjust and always keep their eyes on the prize(s).
2020-06-15.snippet: Golfers went from carping about swab testing to nearly forgetting about social distancing between the ropes, proving a sports truism: Athletes adjust and always keep their eyes on the prize(s).
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: Daniel Berger earned $1.35 million Sunday for winning the PGA Tour’s first tournament after a three-month layoff caused by the coronavirus pandemic. But on Monday Berger was entitled to something more precious: a first-class seat on the special flight the tour chartered to safely shuttle players and their caddies to the next event on the tour.
2020-06-15.headline_main: The PGA Tour’s Return Offered a How-to Guide for Other Leagues

2020-06-15.abstract: Roughly 1.7 billion people have at least one of the underlying health conditions that can worsen cases of the coronavirus, a new analysis shows.
2020-06-15.snippet: Roughly 1.7 billion people have at least one of the underlying health conditions that can worsen cases of the coronavirus, a new analysis shows.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: In just six months, nearly 8 million people worldwide have been stricken with confirmed cases of Covid-19, and at least 434,000 have died. But those deaths have not been distributed evenly; among the most vulnerable are people with underlying health conditions, such as diabetes and diseases that affect the heart and lungs. According to a new modeling study, roughly 1.7 billion people around the world — 22 percent of the global population — fall into that category.
2020-06-15.headline_main: Study Finds 1 in 5 People Worldwide at Risk of Severe Covid-19

2020-06-15.abstract: Two statues of Juan de Oñate are being removed after long-simmering tension between Native Americans and Hispanics over Spain’s conquest of New Mexico.
2020-06-15.snippet: Two statues of Juan de Oñate are being removed after long-simmering tension between Native Americans and Hispanics over Spain’s conquest of New Mexico.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — Gunfire broke out during a protest Monday night in Albuquerque to demand the removal of a statue of Juan de Oñate, the despotic conquistador of New Mexico whose image has become the latest target in demonstrations across the country aimed at righting a history of racial injustice.
2020-06-15.headline_main: Man Is Shot at Protest Over Statue of New Mexico’s Conquistador

2020-06-15.abstract: Once a Detroit educator committed to social justice, he developed a crack addiction and robbed 18 banks in three months, earning the name the “Zombie Bandit.” He died of Covid-19.
2020-06-15.snippet: Once a Detroit educator committed to social justice, he developed a crack addiction and robbed 18 banks in three months, earning the name the “Zombie Bandit.” He died of Covid-19.

2020-06-15.headline_main: Alan Hurwitz, Teacher and Activist Who Turned to Bank Heists, Dies at 79

2020-06-15.abstract: The Supreme Court decision gives plaintiffs leverage, but companies large and small are still expected to face legal cases over their policies.
2020-06-15.snippet: The Supreme Court decision gives plaintiffs leverage, but companies large and small are still expected to face legal cases over their policies.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: When a Walmart associate named Jacqueline Cote filed a charge with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission in 2014 contending that the company was discriminating against her by denying health insurance benefits to her same-sex spouse, it signaled the beginning of a drawn-out legal battle.

2020-06-15.abstract: The Supreme Court says you can’t be fired for being gay or transgender.
2020-06-15.snippet: The Supreme Court says you can’t be fired for being gay or transgender.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: In an emphatic win for civil rights, equal justice and common sense, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday that federal law bars employers from firing workers for being lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender.
2020-06-15.headline_main: Gay Rights Are Civil Rights

2020-06-15.abstract: A troubling pattern emerges in parts of the U.S. that began lifting restrictions earlier than others.

2020-06-15.abstract: Mayor Keisha Lance Bottoms issued a series of executive orders after the shooting of Rayshard Brooks, which has stirred protests and pushed the city into a broader reckoning over policing.
2020-06-15.snippet: Mayor Keisha Lance Bottoms issued a series of executive orders after the shooting of Rayshard Brooks, which has stirred protests and pushed the city into a broader reckoning over policing.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — In the wake of the death of a black motorist by a white Atlanta police officer, the city’s mayor announced on Monday a series of changes aimed at dramatically overhauling how the Police Department uses force.
2020-06-15.headline_main: Atlanta Mayor Tightens Rules on When Police Can Use Force

2020-06-15.abstract: A ruling that protects the rights of gay and transgender workers could affect how conservative groups operate their own institutions.
2020-06-15.snippet: A ruling that protects the rights of gay and transgender workers could affect how conservative groups operate their own institutions.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For conservative Christian groups, Monday’s Supreme Court ruling protecting the rights of gay and transgender workers was not only the latest sign that they are losing the American culture wars over sexuality. It also caused widespread concern that it could affect how they operate their own institutions.
2020-06-15.headline_main: Conservative Christians See ‘Seismic Implications’ in Supreme Court Ruling

2020-06-15.abstract: Federal investigations and public outcry over senators’ stock trades amid the coronavirus crisis have renewed interest in limiting what lawmakers can do with their savings.
2020-06-15.snippet: Federal investigations and public outcry over senators’ stock trades amid the coronavirus crisis have renewed interest in limiting what lawmakers can do with their savings.
2020-06-15.lead_paragraph: The latest campaign ad by Senator Kelly Loeffler, a freshman Republican from Georgia fighting to keep her job, is entitled “CLEARED.” It recounts how she fought back against charges that she improperly traded stocks based on a confidential briefing she received in January about the looming coronavirus crisis. In late May, the Justice Department confirmed that an investigation into the trades did not find evidence that she broke the law.
2020-06-15.headline_main: To Gain Public’s Trust, Should Members of Congress Stop Trading Stock?

2020-06-16.abstract: So much for “But Gorsuch.”

2020-06-16.lead_paragraph: The new season of my favorite television show, “The Good Fight,” begins with the heroine, the feminist lawyer Diane Lockhart, awakening in what seems at first like a giddy alternative reality in which Hillary Clinton won the 2016 election. She remembers the horrors of the last three and a half years, but no one else seems to. A crushing weight lifts as she convinces herself it was all an awful dream.

2020-06-16.lead_paragraph: West Dakota, a drag queen in Brooklyn, was checking in on a fellow drag queen and mentor when they began discussing what they said was a painful reality about the George Floyd protests: Black transgender people are disproportionately the victims of police violence, but attending demonstrations against police brutality can often put them in further danger.
