2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Seattle’s police-free “autonomous zone” is coming to an end.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Don’t Be Fooled by Seattle’s Police-Free Zone

2020-06-24.abstract: After suffering from sleeplessness and anxiety for months, I finally saw a psychiatrist. I became so relaxed so quickly that I passed out.
2020-06-24.snippet: After suffering from sleeplessness and anxiety for months, I finally saw a psychiatrist. I became so relaxed so quickly that I passed out.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: The psychiatrist was bald, with kind eyes, a silver goatee and the air of exhaustion that follows a person who works hard in a difficult field. It was March 2019, and having let an old prescription expire months earlier, I had gone to the Veterans Affairs hospital in Manhattan — my first time at a V.A. — hoping to get antidepressants.
2020-06-24.headline_main: The V.A. Made Me Vomit. And That Was a Good Thing.

2020-06-24.abstract: Fetishizing coding and robots misses the real engines of our economy.
2020-06-24.snippet: Fetishizing coding and robots misses the real engines of our economy.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: The stories we used to tell about work went something like this: The protagonist, a white man wearing a hard hat, has a stable job in manufacturing or construction that allows him to buy a home and work toward a comfortable retirement.
2020-06-24.headline_main: The Future of Work Isn’t What People Think It Is

2020-06-24.abstract: Many infections come from within. Doctors explain what they are and what to do about them.
2020-06-24.snippet: Many infections come from within. Doctors explain what they are and what to do about them.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: In April, about a month into a quarantine so careful I almost forgot how to drive, my 5-year-old came down with what I now refer to as “The Rash.” It started near her right eye, then spread down her right cheek — a red, menacing, puffy splotch. A few days later, it appeared on her left cheek, too. We arranged a telemedicine appointment with her pediatrician, who squinted at it and suggested it might be bacterial and ordered a round of topical and oral antibiotics. The medicines worked for as long as we had them: Exactly 48 hours after we stopped using them the splotches came back.
2020-06-24.headline_main: How Are My Kids Still Getting Sick in Lockdown?

2020-06-24.abstract: How to tax inheritances more fairly.
2020-06-24.snippet: How to tax inheritances more fairly.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: A massive transfer of wealth is underway and will accelerate in the coming years. Baby boomers and the generation that preceded them currently own $84 trillion, or 81 percent of all U.S. household wealth — wealth that will before long be inherited by their children and other beneficiaries.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Tax the Rich and Their Heirs

2020-06-24.abstract: The players said they did not want a photo of them standing during the national anthem to be used for political purposes.
2020-06-24.snippet: The players said they did not want a photo of them standing during the national anthem to be used for political purposes.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: For a few hours this week, softball had a shot at something it has pursued for decades: the spotlight. The USSSA Pride and Scrap Yard Fast Pitch, two independent professional softball teams that feature some of the top players in the world, began what was supposed to be a seven-game series in Melbourne, Fla., facing little competition from other live sports.
2020-06-24.headline_main: A Softball Team’s Tweet to Trump Leads Players to Quit Mid-Series

2020-06-24.abstract: Scientists have discovered the heaviest known neutron star, or maybe the lightest known black hole: “Either way it breaks a record.”
2020-06-24.snippet: Scientists have discovered the heaviest known neutron star, or maybe the lightest known black hole: “Either way it breaks a record.”
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: Astronomers announced today that they had discovered something new out in the dark: a stellar corpse too heavy to be a neutron star — the remnant of a supernova explosion — but not heavy enough to be a black hole.
2020-06-24.headline_main: A Black Hole’s Lunch Provides a Treat for Astronomers

2020-06-24.abstract: In what may be the first known case of its kind, a faulty facial recognition match led to a Michigan man’s arrest for a crime he did not commit.
2020-06-24.snippet: In what may be the first known case of its kind, a faulty facial recognition match led to a Michigan man’s arrest for a crime he did not commit.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: Note: In response to this article, the Wayne County prosecutor’s office said that Robert Julian-Borchak Williams could have the case and his fingerprint data expunged. “We apologize,” the prosecutor, Kym L. Worthy, said in a statement, adding, “This does not in any way make up for the hours that Mr. Williams spent in jail.”
2020-06-24.headline_main: Wrongfully Accused by an Algorithm

2020-06-24.abstract: The coronavirus pandemic is forcing America to confront its epidemic low-wage problem.
2020-06-24.snippet: The coronavirus pandemic is forcing America to confront its epidemic low-wage problem.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: With notable abruptness, thanks to the advent of the coronavirus, much of the public has become aware of its dependence on hospital orderlies, cleaners, trash collectors, grocery workers, food delivery drivers, paramedics, mortuary technicians, and postal, shipping, maintenance, wastewater treatment, truck stop and mass transit employees — on what, to many, had been a largely invisible work force.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Why Do We Pay So Many People So Little Money?

2020-06-24.abstract: A group of transportation experts wants to build a new bridge in New York City to accommodate a surge in cycling.
2020-06-24.snippet: A group of transportation experts wants to build a new bridge in New York City to accommodate a surge in cycling.

2020-06-24.abstract: Lessons from an organic garlic farmer on how to grow, harvest and cure garlic at home.
2020-06-24.snippet: Lessons from an organic garlic farmer on how to grow, harvest and cure garlic at home.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: Every year at about this point in the growing season, Alley Swiss has a ritual he performs. It’s one that humans have done for thousands of years, as they cultivated one of our oldest, most beloved food crops.
2020-06-24.headline_main: The Garlic Will Tell You When It’s Time

2020-06-24.abstract: The director has adapted Michelle McNamara’s true-crime best seller about the Golden State Killer, “I’ll Be Gone in the Dark," into an HBO  series.
2020-06-24.snippet: The director has adapted Michelle McNamara’s true-crime best seller about the Golden State Killer, “I’ll Be Gone in the Dark," into an HBO  series.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: Hollywood may love neat, cathartic resolutions, but the filmmaker Liz Garbus has always been drawn to open-ended stories. “You have to deal a little bit with the discomfort of the gray areas in the world,” she said in a recent phone conversation.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Liz Garbus Is Taking Back the Voices Stolen by the Golden State Killer

2020-06-24.abstract: Many Americans have lost work in the pandemic, and some are turning to their families for help. That can aggravate some awkward dynamics.
2020-06-24.snippet: Many Americans have lost work in the pandemic, and some are turning to their families for help. That can aggravate some awkward dynamics.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: As a financial adviser, Elyse Foster helps clients navigate tricky personal issues around managing their money. But the coronavirus has brought an extra layer of complexity — especially where family is concerned.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Your Brother (or Sister or Mother) Is Asking for Money. Now What?

2020-06-24.abstract: Blocks from where George Floyd drew his last breaths, residents have vowed to avoid the police to protect people of color. The commitment is hard to keep.
2020-06-24.snippet: Blocks from where George Floyd drew his last breaths, residents have vowed to avoid the police to protect people of color. The commitment is hard to keep.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — When Shari Albers moved three decades ago into Powderhorn Park, a tree-lined Minneapolis neighborhood known as a haven to leftist activists and bohemian artists like herself, she went to work sprucing it up.
2020-06-24.headline_main: A Minneapolis Neighborhood Vowed to Check Its Privilege. It’s Already Being Tested.

2020-06-24.abstract: As mass infections strike even in places that had seemed to tame the coronavirus, officials are turning to targeted and fast-but-flexible approaches to stop third or fourth waves.
2020-06-24.snippet: As mass infections strike even in places that had seemed to tame the coronavirus, officials are turning to targeted and fast-but-flexible approaches to stop third or fourth waves.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: China is testing restaurant workers and delivery drivers block by block. South Korea tells people to carry two types of masks for differing risky social situations. Germany requires communities to crack down when the number of infections hits certain thresholds. Britain will target local outbreaks in a strategy that Prime Minister Boris Johnson calls “Whac-A-Mole.”
2020-06-24.headline_main: From China to Germany, the World Learns to Live With the Coronavirus

2020-06-24.abstract: As travelers seek safety amid social distancing, the travel industry is adapting with outdoor trips, remote lodgings and private camps.
2020-06-24.snippet: As travelers seek safety amid social distancing, the travel industry is adapting with outdoor trips, remote lodgings and private camps.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: From taking cooking classes in the home of a local to learning traditional crafts from Indigenous people, much of travel — up until March 2020 — was all about connecting with others.
2020-06-24.headline_main: The New Escapism: Isolationist Travel

2020-06-24.abstract: From racist graffiti to missed promotions, employees say a “systemic pattern of racial bias” permeates the company.
2020-06-24.snippet: From racist graffiti to missed promotions, employees say a “systemic pattern of racial bias” permeates the company.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Last week, Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive, wrote a rare note to all of the company’s employees. His leadership team had been reflecting on the “systemic racism” facing black communities, he said, and he urged employees to take time to learn and reflect on Juneteenth, the holiday marking the end of slavery in the United States.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Amazon Workers Urge Bezos to Match His Words on Race With Actions

2020-06-24.abstract: Tyana Johnson was killed and three others were wounded when men opened fire at her party in a Bronx park. The police have few leads.
2020-06-24.snippet: Tyana Johnson was killed and three others were wounded when men opened fire at her party in a Bronx park. The police have few leads.

2020-06-24.headline_main: A Teenager Hosted a Graduation Party. Then 2 Gunmen Showed Up.

2020-06-24.abstract: A memoir from the poet Natasha Trethewey; “Hamnet,” Maggie O’Farrell’s novel about Shakespeare; and “Too Much and Never Enough,” an exposé about President Trump by his niece.
2020-06-24.snippet: A memoir from the poet Natasha Trethewey; “Hamnet,” Maggie O’Farrell’s novel about Shakespeare; and “Too Much and Never Enough,” an exposé about President Trump by his niece.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: After the “Manfall” pandemic wipes out most of the men on the planet, Cole disguises her son — one of the last males on Earth — as a girl and tries to get him to safety before the government can snatch him. Their cross-country journey is treacherous, as they evade not only the Department of Men but also Cole’s sister, Billie, who is determined to separate mother and son. Beukes’s imagined world — complete with bootleg sperm and faux baby bumps — is a thrilling setting for an examination of maternal love.
2020-06-24.headline_main: 16 Books to Watch For in July

2020-06-24.abstract: With their colossal limestone walls and gloriously green valleys, Italy’s Dolomites are home to some of the world’s most majestic scenery — and mountain huts called rifugios make it all the more accessible.
2020-06-24.snippet: With their colossal limestone walls and gloriously green valleys, Italy’s Dolomites are home to some of the world’s most majestic scenery — and mountain huts called rifugios make it all the more accessible.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: With travel restrictions in place worldwide, we’ve launched a new series, The World Through a Lens, in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Mónica R. Goya shares a series of photographs taken on an extended hike through the Dolomites.
2020-06-24.headline_main: The Haunting Beauty of a Hut-to-Hut Hike in the Dolomites

2020-06-24.abstract: Workers have been left behind as the U.S. economy expanded and chief executive salaries skyrocketed over the last four decades.
2020-06-24.snippet: Workers have been left behind as the U.S. economy expanded and chief executive salaries skyrocketed over the last four decades.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: Over the past four decades, American workers have suffered a devastating loss of economic power, manifest in their wages, benefits and working conditions. The annual economic output of the United States has almost tripled, but, with the help of policymakers from both political parties, the wealthy hoarded the fruits.
2020-06-24.headline_main: The Jobs We Need

2020-06-24.abstract: Statues and monuments that have long honored racist figures are being boxed up, spray-painted — or beheaded.
2020-06-24.snippet: Statues and monuments that have long honored racist figures are being boxed up, spray-painted — or beheaded.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: The statues have stood for more than a century in some places. Some are cast in bronze, others carved in stone. And all over the world, as protests against racism and police violence have renewed attention on legacies of injustices, people have been asking: Does this statue still need to be here?
2020-06-24.headline_main: How Statues Are Falling Around the World

2020-06-24.abstract: In the South Bronx, the coronavirus had a devastating impact on an already vulnerable population. Residents of public housing didn’t wait for the city to help.
2020-06-24.snippet: In the South Bronx, the coronavirus had a devastating impact on an already vulnerable population. Residents of public housing didn’t wait for the city to help.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: A walk along 138th Street in Mott Haven offers a blunt diagnosis of a South Bronx community troubled by chronic, and preventable, illnesses. Asthma, obesity and diabetes — which has spawned its own economy, reflected in signs on lampposts offering cash for test strips — have put the Bronx at the bottom of New York’s health rankings.
2020-06-24.headline_main: ‘The City Fumbled It’: How 4 Families Took On the Virus

On our last visit, I learned the table is one of many of my father-in-law’s creations. Others include a linguistics book, two daughters, and one son, Vinh, who is my husband.

Putin on Wednesday celebrated his country’s victory 75 years ago against Nazi Germany, presiding over an enormous military parade through Red Square that featured thousands of soldiers marching shoulder-to-shoulder without face masks.

2020-06-24.abstract: Digitized newspaper archives and hyperlocal historical sources can help you understand how your ancestors lived.
2020-06-24.snippet: Digitized newspaper archives and hyperlocal historical sources can help you understand how your ancestors lived.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: Long before the internet made it easy to share the nuances of daily life, local newspapers and other regional publications reported the business, society and civic news of the people in the community. For budding genealogists, finding an ancestor in an old microfilmed newspaper and reading contemporaneous accounts of her turn in the school play or his all-city bowling championship provide a glimpse into the past that’s more textured than a chart of names and dates.
2020-06-24.headline_main: How to Dig Up Family History Online

2020-06-24.snippet: A waterfront bungalow on Bainbridge Island, a modern sanctuary in Los Angeles and an expanded late 18th-century farmhouse on more than 85 acres in Dummerston.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: This house is in the Eagledale neighborhood, with filtered views of Eagle Harbor and its marina. The ferry terminal (along with restaurants, a winery, a museum and a waterfront park) is a 10-minute car ride around the harbor, and the ferry ride to Seattle is 35 minutes. The property has 180 feet of frontage on a tidal inlet called Whiskey Creek, so named because it was rumored to have been used for stashing and transporting liquor from Canada during Prohibition.

2020-06-24.abstract: These shows may fill in some of the gaps left by your school curriculum and deepen your understanding of what’s happening now.
2020-06-24.snippet: These shows may fill in some of the gaps left by your school curriculum and deepen your understanding of what’s happening now.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: Even with half of the year left, it’s already clear 2020 will be one for the history books. A deadly pandemic, economic collapse, and a reckoning on race and police brutality will ensure that this year will be remembered as one of seismic change. And in times of uncertainty and upheaval, one of the best ways to understand the future is to look to the past.
2020-06-24.headline_main: 7 Podcasts For History Buffs

2020-06-24.abstract: A proposed rule would keep plans from increasing risk or decreasing returns in pursuit of “a social or political end,” Secretary Eugene Scalia says. But others say existing law achieves that end.
2020-06-24.snippet: A proposed rule would keep plans from increasing risk or decreasing returns in pursuit of “a social or political end,” Secretary Eugene Scalia says. But others say existing law achieves that end.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: The Labor Department is seeking a new federal regulation that could discourage retirement funds from making investments based on environmental, social and governance considerations.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Labor Dept. Seeks to Restrict Social Goals in Retirement Investing

2020-06-24.abstract: Following the 2018 success of Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, three progressive Democrats took commanding leads in their primaries.
2020-06-24.snippet: Following the 2018 success of Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, three progressive Democrats took commanding leads in their primaries.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: Candidates from the Democratic Party’s left wing held significant leads in three marquee House primaries in New York after Tuesday’s machine ballot count, in a profound show of progressive political power.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Insurgent Wave Upends House Primaries in N.Y. as Engel Falls Behind

2020-06-24.abstract: The art museum in Florence was one of the first to use the social media platform, posting unusually irreverent videos that challenge its dignified reputation.
2020-06-24.snippet: The art museum in Florence was one of the first to use the social media platform, posting unusually irreverent videos that challenge its dignified reputation.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Last month, the Uffizi Gallery in Florence — long a bastion of tradition — posted a video to its TikTok account featuring Botticelli’s “Spring.” The painting depicts Venus and other mythological figures, and has been gawked at by tourists and studied by academics for centuries.
2020-06-24.headline_main: As Museums Get on TikTok, the Uffizi Is an Unlikely Class Clown

2020-06-24.abstract: Two appellate judges ordered a lower-court judge to dismiss a charge against President Trump’s former national security adviser. A third judge accused them of overstepping their powers.
2020-06-24.snippet: Two appellate judges ordered a lower-court judge to dismiss a charge against President Trump’s former national security adviser. A third judge accused them of overstepping their powers.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A divided federal appeals court panel ordered an immediate end on Wednesday to the case against Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s former national security adviser — delivering a major victory to Mr. Flynn and to the Justice Department, which had sought to drop the case.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Appeals Court Panel Orders End to Michael Flynn Case

2020-06-24.abstract: Up your lunch sandwich game, with some no-recipe recipe prompts, and make Yotam Ottolenghi’s latest — a potato cake, two ways — for dinner.
2020-06-24.snippet: Up your lunch sandwich game, with some no-recipe recipe prompts, and make Yotam Ottolenghi’s latest — a potato cake, two ways — for dinner.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: Good morning. It was Emily Weinstein who got me to slice and freeze my bread so that it makes better toast.
2020-06-24.headline_main: What to Cook Right Now

2020-06-24.abstract: Tired of searching for good movies to stream and looking for something off the beaten path? We did the work for you.
2020-06-24.snippet: Tired of searching for good movies to stream and looking for something off the beaten path? We did the work for you.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: Weeks have stretched into months, and many of us are still spending a lot of our time inside, staring down an ever-shrinking queue of must-see movies. So it’s time to take some chances again, going beyond streaming platforms’ carefully curated front-page recommendations to check out less obvious choices: gnarly genre films, riveting documentaries, indie dramas and more of what’s hiding in the back rooms of your subscription services.
2020-06-24.headline_main: 10 Streaming Movies to Take a Chance On

2020-06-24.abstract: President Hashim Thaci, who was scheduled to visit the White House on Saturday, faces 10 counts of war crimes brought by prosecutors at a special court in the Netherlands.
2020-06-24.snippet: President Hashim Thaci, who was scheduled to visit the White House on Saturday, faces 10 counts of war crimes brought by prosecutors at a special court in the Netherlands.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — President Hashim Thaci of Kosovo, a guerrilla leader during Kosovo’s battle for independence from Serbia during the 1990s, was indicted on 10 counts of war crimes on Wednesday at a special court in the Netherlands. Prosecutors accused him and other former fighters of being “criminally responsible for nearly 100 murders.”
2020-06-24.headline_main: Kosovo President Is Indicted for War Crimes for Role in War With Serbia

2020-06-24.abstract: The pianist and “Late Show” bandleader has been bringing musical wake-up calls to events across New York.
2020-06-24.snippet: The pianist and “Late Show” bandleader has been bringing musical wake-up calls to events across New York.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: Jon Batiste, the jazz pianist and “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert” bandleader, has spent the last three weekends marching in the streets of New York, leading musicians and protesters through hymns and songs like “We Shall Overcome” and “Down by the Riverside.” Those without a horn or drum sing and, at Mr. Batiste’s exhortation, say their names: George Floyd. Breonna Taylor. And many others.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Jazz Is Built for Protests. Jon Batiste Is Taking It to the Streets.

2020-06-24.abstract: “We are running out of options here,” Mayor Bill de Blasio said, referring to the economic impact of the outbreak. “That is the blunt truth.”
2020-06-24.snippet: “We are running out of options here,” Mayor Bill de Blasio said, referring to the economic impact of the outbreak. “That is the blunt truth.”
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio and other top officials warned on Wednesday that the coronavirus pandemic was putting tremendous stress on the finances of government in New York City, raising the prospect that they might have to carry out cuts in infrastructure spending and some of the most sweeping layoffs of municipal workers in decades.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Pandemic May Force New York City to Lay Off 22,000 Workers

2020-06-24.abstract: Rather than tear down statues, some argue that the past should not be obliterated, but remembered and explained.
2020-06-24.snippet: Rather than tear down statues, some argue that the past should not be obliterated, but remembered and explained.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: BORDEAUX, France — At a bend in the river, a succession of stately stone buildings, each more imposing than the last, stretches along the left bank. Their elegant 18th-century facades had helped Bordeaux, already famous for its wineries, become a UNESCO World Heritage site.
2020-06-24.headline_main: George Floyd’s Killing Forces Wider Debate on France’s Slave-Trading Past

2020-06-24.abstract: Whether you’re scrolling through TikTok or watching people at the park, it’s hard to ignore skaters gliding by this summer.
2020-06-24.snippet: Whether you’re scrolling through TikTok or watching people at the park, it’s hard to ignore skaters gliding by this summer.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: Jessie Zhang, an 18-year-old in Northern California, is dying for roller skates. She’s spent hours scouring the internet looking at different skate designs. She has researched toe guards on Depop. And she’s even been picking up extra chores around the house, like doing the dishes, in hopes that her parents will buy her a pair.
2020-06-24.headline_main: The Summer of Roller Skates

2020-06-24.abstract: The sale follows outcry over comments Mr. Glassman made about the death of George Floyd and reports of sexual harassment under his management.
2020-06-24.snippet: The sale follows outcry over comments Mr. Glassman made about the death of George Floyd and reports of sexual harassment under his management.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: Greg Glassman, the embattled owner of CrossFit who was the subject of a recent article in The New York Times detailing routine sexual harassment of female employees, intends to sell the fitness brand to Eric Roza, according to a message sent to affiliate gym owners by the company’s chief executive, Dave Castro.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Greg Glassman, Embattled Owner of CrossFit, to Sell His Company

2020-06-24.abstract: New Jersey and Connecticut will also require visitors to quarantine for two weeks. The rule reflects a stark shift in the course of the outbreak.
2020-06-24.snippet: New Jersey and Connecticut will also require visitors to quarantine for two weeks. The rule reflects a stark shift in the course of the outbreak.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: A few months ago, New York was suffering through the worst ravages of the coronavirus pandemic. Hospitals filled to near capacity. Hundreds of people died each day, reaching a peak in mid-April.
2020-06-24.headline_main: N.Y. Will Impose Quarantine on Visitors From States With Big Outbreaks

2020-06-24.abstract: The fashion designer Thakoon Panichgul and the creative director Russell Spina learn to make work and personal life happen in their two-bedroom Manhattan loft.
2020-06-24.snippet: The fashion designer Thakoon Panichgul and the creative director Russell Spina learn to make work and personal life happen in their two-bedroom Manhattan loft.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: The key to staying sane while sheltering in place for the fashion designer Thakoon Panichgul and the creative director Russell Spina is connection. The couple, who have been together for 20 years, have spent the last three months quarantined in their two-bedroom loft in Manhattan’s TriBeCa neighborhood. This has allowed them to continue to support their favorite local businesses like Chamber Street Wines and the neighborhood pizza joint, Tre Sorelle on Reade Street.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Embracing Work-Life Balance at the Dining Room Table

2020-06-24.abstract: Also this week, how to help reinvent your workplace.
2020-06-24.snippet: Also this week, how to help reinvent your workplace.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter! Join us on July 9 for the debut of Netting Zero, a series of virtual events looking ahead to key international climate negotiations next year. The first panel, Applying Covid-19’s Hard-Earned Lessons to Climate Change, will be moderated by Hannah Fairfield, who leads the Times climate desk. You can register here.
2020-06-24.headline_main: How a Ruling on Gay and Transgender Rights May Help the Climate

2020-06-24.abstract: “Mädchen in Uniform,” a classic account of forbidden love in a girl’s boarding school, is both an expression of anti-fascism and a lesbian coming-out story.
2020-06-24.snippet: “Mädchen in Uniform,” a classic account of forbidden love in a girl’s boarding school, is both an expression of anti-fascism and a lesbian coming-out story.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: One of the most popular German movies of 1931 was also the most radical — although it is not always recognized as such. “Mädchen in Uniform,” directed by Leontine Sagan with Carl Froelich, is a love story involving an adolescent girl and her primly seductive teacher.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Women in Revolt: Erotic Liberation on Film in 1930s Germany

2020-06-24.abstract: The internet company has long been criticized about how much information it keeps on users. The change applies only to new accounts.
2020-06-24.snippet: The internet company has long been criticized about how much information it keeps on users. The change applies only to new accounts.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — After years of criticism about how it keeps a record of what people do online, Google said it would start automatically deleting location history and records of web and app activity as well as voice recordings on new accounts after 18 months.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Google Sets Limit on How Long It Will Store Some Data

2020-06-24.abstract: The confirmation of the Mississippian, over Democratic opposition, fills the final appeals court vacancy and makes him the 200th judge installed by President Trump.
2020-06-24.snippet: The confirmation of the Mississippian, over Democratic opposition, fills the final appeals court vacancy and makes him the 200th judge installed by President Trump.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: The Senate on Wednesday confirmed Cory T. Wilson of Mississippi to a New Orleans-based circuit court over united Democratic opposition, handing President Trump the 200th federal judicial confirmation of his tenure and achieving a Republican goal of filling every appeals court opening by the end of the year.
2020-06-24.headline_main: With Wilson Confirmation, Trump and Senate Republicans Achieve a Milestone

2020-06-24.abstract: The government, after years of delays, is finally clarifying rules on tax breaks for companies that use carbon capture to fight climate change.
2020-06-24.snippet: The government, after years of delays, is finally clarifying rules on tax breaks for companies that use carbon capture to fight climate change.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Carbon capture, a rarely tested strategy to fight climate change, is attracting growing interest in the United States after the Trump administration began clearing a longstanding roadblock to subsidizing the technology.

2020-06-24.abstract: We’re considering the way forward, but it bears repeating: We’re safest at home.
2020-06-24.snippet: We’re considering the way forward, but it bears repeating: We’re safest at home.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: Welcome. What does it mean now, to be “at home”? Not so long ago we nonessential people were quarantined, hiding out from an invisible foe, either circled tight with family or flying solo, peeking out the windows at the scary world without. We awoke at home, spent the day at home, went to bed at home. One newsroom wag declared time changed forever: coffee time, wine time, sleep time. Everything else was work, even if you weren’t working. We were all just stacking time, at home.
2020-06-24.headline_main: The Best Ideas for Living Right Now

2020-06-24.abstract: The pilots ignored repeated warnings that they were flying too high approaching Karachi’s airport, and failed to lower the landing gear, according to a preliminary report.
2020-06-24.snippet: The pilots ignored repeated warnings that they were flying too high approaching Karachi’s airport, and failed to lower the landing gear, according to a preliminary report.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: The pilots of a Pakistani airliner that crashed last month in Karachi were busy talking about the coronavirus and repeatedly ignored directions from air traffic controllers before their plane went down, killing 98 people, Pakistan’s aviation minister said Wednesday.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Pilots Discussed Coronavirus, Ignoring Alerts Before Pakistan Crash, Officials Say

2020-06-24.abstract: Galleries and museums are getting creative about presenting work online during the coronavirus crisis. Here are two shows worth viewing virtually.
2020-06-24.snippet: Galleries and museums are getting creative about presenting work online during the coronavirus crisis. Here are two shows worth viewing virtually.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: The roving project space We Buy Gold has turned to the painter Nina Chanel Abney to organize this online video exhibition of nearly a dozen artists who frame the body, most often black, in states of tension or rejuvenation, discomfort or grace. One above all commands attention: “Suspension,” a new work by the Johannesburg artist Thenjiwe Niki Nkosi, which stitches together archival footage of elite gymnasts into a seven-minute ode to personal and collective virtuosity.
2020-06-24.headline_main: 2 Art Gallery Shows to Explore From Home

2020-06-24.abstract: Creamy, herby and drinkable, this meal is ready after a few minutes in the blender.
2020-06-24.snippet: Creamy, herby and drinkable, this meal is ready after a few minutes in the blender.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: When it’s too hot to cook, there’s a long, vast tradition of chilled soups to save the day. Be they gazpacho, borscht, shav or a creamy, yogurt-based cucumber soup seasoned with garlic and herbs, there are few summer lunches as cooling and satisfying.
2020-06-24.headline_main: This Is One Cool Cucumber Soup

2020-06-24.abstract: Black soldiers finally get their own story, but in one important respect, the film is no different from other Hollywood dramas that came before.
2020-06-24.snippet: Black soldiers finally get their own story, but in one important respect, the film is no different from other Hollywood dramas that came before.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: All wars are fought twice, the first time on the battlefield, the second time in memory. This is certainly true for what Americans call the “Vietnam War” and what the victorious Vietnamese call the “American War.” Both terms obscure how a war that killed more than 58,000 Americans and three million Vietnamese was also fought in Laos and Cambodia, killing hundreds of thousands more and leading directly to the Cambodian genocide.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Vietnamese Lives, American Imperialist Views, Even in ‘Da 5 Bloods’

2020-06-24.snippet: The authorities said that no injuries had been reported, but that campgrounds near Mount Whitney had been evacuated after a rockslide in the area.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: A strong earthquake struck Central California on Wednesday, causing store shelves to fall and setting off a rockslide near Mount Whitney, where campgrounds were evacuated, according to the local authorities.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Strong Earthquake Strikes Central California

2020-06-24.abstract: An independent report on the coronavirus outbreak at the Holyoke Soldiers’ Home describes “the opposite of infection control,” as administrators combined wards of infected and uninfected patients.

2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — An investigation of 76 deaths linked to the coronavirus at a state-run veterans’ home in Massachusetts paints a picture of a facility in chaos, as traumatized nurses carried out orders to combine wards of infected and uninfected men, knowing that the move would prove deadly to many of their patients.
2020-06-24.headline_main: ‘Total Pandemonium’: What Went Wrong at a Veterans’ Home Where 76 Died

2020-06-24.abstract: A married pair of virologists in Moscow tested a vaccine on their own children in the 1950s. Now, a side effect they found is sparking new hope for a defense against the coronavirus.
2020-06-24.snippet: A married pair of virologists in Moscow tested a vaccine on their own children in the 1950s. Now, a side effect they found is sparking new hope for a defense against the coronavirus.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — To the boys, it was just a sugary treat. To their parents, prominent medical researchers, what happened in their Moscow apartment that day in 1959 was a vital experiment with countless lives at stake — and their own children as guinea pigs.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Decades-Old Soviet Studies Hint at Coronavirus Strategy

2020-06-24.headline_main: What’s Really Behind the Gender Gap in Covid-19 Deaths?

2020-06-24.headline_main: Senate Questions C.I.A. Watchdog Nominee Over Independence

2020-06-24.abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu wants to annex territory along the Jordan border. Palestinian residents wonder where that leaves them.
2020-06-24.snippet: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu wants to annex territory along the Jordan border. Palestinian residents wonder where that leaves them.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: AL JIFTILIK, West Bank — Hamdan Saeed rises at 5:30 each morning to sell hot coffee to Palestinian and Israeli motorists along Route 90, the main highway through the Jordan Valley, a resource-rich borderland in the occupied West Bank.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Palestinians in Jordan Valley Fear Annexation Would Choke Off Their Villages

2020-06-24.abstract: The fire department is investigating arson as a possible cause.
2020-06-24.snippet: The fire department is investigating arson as a possible cause.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A soaring wood spire by artist Andy Goldsworthy in the Presidio national park that has proved popular with art-seekers and nature-lovers alike was damaged by fire early Tuesday morning. The fire was quickly extinguished but the sculpture was extensively charred.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Andy Goldsworthy Sculpture in San Francisco Is Damaged by Fire

2020-06-24.abstract: In this delicate movie, a teenage girl in Seoul tries to find a sense of self amid calamities small and large.
2020-06-24.snippet: In this delicate movie, a teenage girl in Seoul tries to find a sense of self amid calamities small and large.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: At one point near the end of “House of Hummingbird,” a teenage girl stands and looks intently at the world around her. She’s in a throng of schoolgirls in matching uniforms, all laughing and teasingly jostling one another. Often these girls look anxious while trying to get their footing in that unstable terrain called adolescence, but now, together, they seem happy, free. As the scene continues, a woman speaks in voice-over. “The world is fascinating and beautiful.” Our girl has hit several rough patches, but from the way she keeps looking at the world you know she’ll be OK.
2020-06-24.headline_main: ‘House of Hummingbird’ Review: Picture a Girl, Picture a World

2020-06-24.abstract: The three white men accused of killing Mr. Arbery, a black man who was chased while jogging in their neighborhood, were each indicted on nine counts, including felony murder.
2020-06-24.snippet: The three white men accused of killing Mr. Arbery, a black man who was chased while jogging in their neighborhood, were each indicted on nine counts, including felony murder.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The three white men accused of killing Ahmaud Arbery, a black man who was shot dead after being chased in a South Georgia neighborhood, have been indicted on murder charges by a Georgia grand jury, the prosecutor in the case announced on Wednesday.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Suspects in Ahmaud Arbery’s Killing Are Indicted on Murder Charges

2020-06-24.abstract: Having a seat at the table is good, but people of color need to be able to set the agenda too.
2020-06-24.snippet: Having a seat at the table is good, but people of color need to be able to set the agenda too.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: I have worked in politics for over 30 years. For most of those years, there have rarely been black or brown faces at the top level of most campaigns I’ve worked on. I am often the lone voice telling a room full of campaign professionals what it’s like to be pulled over by the police when you’re a brown man.
2020-06-24.headline_main: The People Running Campaigns Don’t Look Like Me

2020-06-24.abstract: His books about Thoreau, Emerson and William James won him national awards — and a fan letter from the celebrated author who would become his wife.
2020-06-24.snippet: His books about Thoreau, Emerson and William James won him national awards — and a fan letter from the celebrated author who would become his wife.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: Robert D. Richardson Jr., whose work as the biographer of Henry Thoreau, Ralph Waldo Emerson and William James was acclaimed as “a virtual intellectual genealogy of American liberalism and, indeed, of American intellectual life in general,” died on June 16 in Hyannis, Mass. He was 86.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Robert Richardson Jr., Biographer of Literary Giants, Dies at 86

2020-06-24.abstract: Cornelius Fredericks, 16, said “I can’t breathe” before becoming unresponsive as he was being restrained at the Lakeside Academy in Kalamazoo in April, according to a state report and lawsuit.
2020-06-24.snippet: Cornelius Fredericks, 16, said “I can’t breathe” before becoming unresponsive as he was being restrained at the Lakeside Academy in Kalamazoo in April, according to a state report and lawsuit.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: Three staff members at a youth academy in Michigan were charged on Wednesday with causing the death of a 16-year-old boy who was killed after two of them put their weight across his chest and abdomen and the third failed to seek medical attention, according to a county prosecutor.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Three Charged in Death of Michigan Teenager Restrained at Youth Academy

2020-06-24.abstract: Dr. Smith’s meticulous research established household pollution as one of the leading causes of disease and death in the developing world.
2020-06-24.snippet: Dr. Smith’s meticulous research established household pollution as one of the leading causes of disease and death in the developing world.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: When Kirk R. Smith began his research career in the 1970s, he was studying the health risks posed by nuclear power. But after a trip to rural parts of Asia, he detected an even bigger threat, affecting more people: toxic fumes being spewed from the solid fuels that heat the humble chulha, a small indoor cooking stove made of mud and clay and used by more than 40 percent of the world’s population.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Kirk Smith, Towering Figure in Environmental Science, Dies at 73

2020-06-24.abstract: William Wesley, better known as World Wide Wes, has long been an hugely influential, if largely unofficial, figure in college and pro basketball.
2020-06-24.snippet: William Wesley, better known as World Wide Wes, has long been an hugely influential, if largely unofficial, figure in college and pro basketball.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: The Knicks, persistently in the market for credibility, clout and connections, made a move to address all three shortcomings on Wednesday by adding one of basketball’s best-known outsiders to the team’s front office.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Knicks Add a Well-Connected Player to Their Front Office

2020-06-24.abstract: The Washington N.F.L. franchise spent this week removing a monument and remembrances honoring its former owner, George Preston Marshall, from team facilities and its website.
2020-06-24.snippet: The Washington N.F.L. franchise spent this week removing a monument and remembrances honoring its former owner, George Preston Marshall, from team facilities and its website.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: George Preston Marshall, the original owner of the N.F.L. team in Washington that was the last franchise to integrate its roster, will have his name removed from the team’s stadium and website.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Redskins Cling to Team’s Name but Erase Former Owner’s

2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: Some sights are so searing that you can’t unsee them. And, like it or not, you end up seeing the world through them. Reality hasn’t changed; you have, which makes you want to change reality. Right now.
2020-06-24.headline_main: We Don’t Have to Like Them. We Just Need to Understand Them.

2020-06-24.snippet: The Democratic National Committee is changing its plans for the August event, at which Joe Biden will accept the presidential nomination, because of coronavirus concerns.

2020-06-24.abstract: The police chief of Tucson, Ariz., offered to step down after the release of a video depicting the death of a handcuffed man. Three officers involved have already resigned.
2020-06-24.snippet: The police chief of Tucson, Ariz., offered to step down after the release of a video depicting the death of a handcuffed man. Three officers involved have already resigned.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: The police chief of Tucson, Ariz., abruptly offered to resign on Wednesday while releasing a video in which a 27-year-old Latino man, Carlos Ingram Lopez, died in police custody two months ago. Mayor Regina Romero on Thursday expressed confidence in the police chief, Chris Magnus, and said he would stay on the job.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Tucson Police in Turmoil After Death of Latino Man in Custody

2020-06-24.abstract: Special Operations forces used a secret weapon designed to limit civilian casualties to strike the Qaeda veteran this month.
2020-06-24.snippet: Special Operations forces used a secret weapon designed to limit civilian casualties to strike the Qaeda veteran this month.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American Special Operations forces used a specially designed secret missile to kill the head of a Qaeda affiliate in Syria this month, dealing the terrorist group a serious blow with a weapon that combines medieval brutality with advanced technology.
2020-06-24.headline_main: U.S. Used Missile With Long Blades to Kill Qaeda Leader in Syria

2020-06-24.headline_main: A Poet Whose Calling Is Doubt Celebrates Language’s Uncertainty

2020-06-24.abstract: The lack of race results in New York and Kentucky this week is a prelude for the presidential election, as officials strain to deal with a deluge of absentee ballots and a jumble of voting deadlines.
2020-06-24.snippet: The lack of race results in New York and Kentucky this week is a prelude for the presidential election, as officials strain to deal with a deluge of absentee ballots and a jumble of voting deadlines.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: The cliffhanger elections on Tuesday night in Kentucky and New York didn’t just leave the candidates and voters in a state of suspended animation wondering who had won. Election officials, lawyers and political strategists in both parties said the lack of results was a bracing preview of what could come after the polls close in November: No clear and immediate winner in the presidential race.
2020-06-24.headline_main: A Winner on Election Day in November? Don’t Count on It

2020-06-24.abstract: A rocket scientist in the Soviet Union, he became a U.S. citizen long after the Cold War ended. “I’m not a defector,” he said. “I like this country.”
2020-06-24.snippet: A rocket scientist in the Soviet Union, he became a U.S. citizen long after the Cold War ended. “I’m not a defector,” he said. “I like this country.”
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: Sergei N. Khrushchev, a former Soviet rocket scientist and the son of Nikita S. Khrushchev, the Soviet leader during the Cold War of the 1950s and ’60s, died on June 18 at his home in Cranston, R.I. He was 84.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Sergei Khrushchev, Son of Former Soviet Premier, Dies at 84

2020-06-24.abstract: Although investigators determined that the knot was not meant as a hate crime targeting Bubba Wallace, the auto racing giant has long had complaints of racist behavior from people within the sport.
2020-06-24.snippet: Although investigators determined that the knot was not meant as a hate crime targeting Bubba Wallace, the auto racing giant has long had complaints of racist behavior from people within the sport.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: Darrell Wallace Jr. said he was relieved to hear the F.B.I. say he had not been the target of a hate crime at Talladega Superspeedway last weekend, after a noose hanging in his garage stall was found to have been there since at least last fall.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Talladega Noose Incident Puts Spotlight on NASCAR’s Troubles With Racism

2020-06-24.abstract: The president’s assertions about widespread fraud have little or no basis in fact but are resonating with his supporters and give him the option of raising doubts about the legitimacy of the outcome.
2020-06-24.snippet: The president’s assertions about widespread fraud have little or no basis in fact but are resonating with his supporters and give him the option of raising doubts about the legitimacy of the outcome.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: President Trump is stepping up his attacks on the integrity of the election system, sowing doubts about the November vote at a time when the pandemic has upended normal balloting and as polls show former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. ahead by large margins.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Trump’s False Attacks on Voting by Mail Stir Broad Concern

2020-06-24.abstract: “It’s going away” only in the president’s delusion.
2020-06-24.snippet: “It’s going away” only in the president’s delusion.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: President Trump says the coronavirus is “fading away” and pats himself on the back for “a great job on CoronaVirus” that saved “millions of U.S. lives.”
2020-06-24.headline_main: Trump Is Feeding America’s Coronavirus Nightmare

2020-06-24.abstract: The president’s message to his die-hard fans is increasingly at odds with how most Americans feel.
2020-06-24.snippet: The president’s message to his die-hard fans is increasingly at odds with how most Americans feel.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Trump, Out of Step

2020-06-24.abstract: Greg Abbott, the Republican governor of the country’s largest Republican-controlled state, is facing increasing pressure over his decision to open the economy.
2020-06-24.snippet: Greg Abbott, the Republican governor of the country’s largest Republican-controlled state, is facing increasing pressure over his decision to open the economy.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The coronavirus has been testing America’s governors. Few are being squeezed harder than Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Virus Cases Are Soaring in Texas. But Closing Down Again Is a ‘Last Option.’

2020-06-24.abstract: That study about dexamethasone has arrived with a big asterisk: While it appears to help severely ill patients, it harms others.
2020-06-24.snippet: That study about dexamethasone has arrived with a big asterisk: While it appears to help severely ill patients, it harms others.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: Scientists in Britain announced a major breakthrough in the battle against the coronavirus last week, reporting they had found the first drug to reduce deaths among critically ill Covid-19 patients.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Breakthrough Drug for Covid-19 May Be Risky for Mild Cases

2020-06-24.abstract: M.L.B. has a new 113-page manual with protocols to keep players and staff members from getting infected by the virus during its upcoming, shortened season.
2020-06-24.snippet: M.L.B. has a new 113-page manual with protocols to keep players and staff members from getting infected by the virus during its upcoming, shortened season.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: Coronavirus testing every other day for players and coaches. Wet rags for pitchers’ pockets to prevent them from licking their fingers. Masks in the dugout and bullpen for any non-players. And no public transportation to the stadium, communal food spreads, saunas, fighting, spitting, smokeless tobacco or sunflower seeds.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Baseball’s New Rules: No Spitting, No Arguing, and Lots of Testing

2020-06-24.abstract: The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe set up checkpoints to limit the spread of the coronavirus. After the state objected, the White House got involved. Now the tribe has asked a federal judge to intervene.
2020-06-24.snippet: The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe set up checkpoints to limit the spread of the coronavirus. After the state objected, the White House got involved. Now the tribe has asked a federal judge to intervene.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Plagued with an inadequate health care system and fearful of what could happen if the coronavirus spread across its tribal lands in South Dakota, the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe took emergency steps 12 weeks ago, setting up checkpoints along roads into its reservation to question travelers about their health and their travel plans.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Tribe in South Dakota Seeks Court Ruling Over Standoff on Blocking Virus

2020-06-24.abstract: The daily number of new cases in the U.S. is almost as high as it was in late April, when the virus first peaked.
2020-06-24.snippet: The daily number of new cases in the U.S. is almost as high as it was in late April, when the virus first peaked.
2020-06-24.lead_paragraph: The U.S. recorded more than 35,000 new cases yesterday — the highest daily total since the outbreak first peaked in late April. More than half of all states saw increasing new cases, and governors across political lines moved to delay or reverse reopenings.
2020-06-24.headline_main: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today

2020-06-25.abstract: Florida, Texas, Oklahoma and South Carolina set daily records. Nationwide, more than 36,000 cases were reported Wednesday.
2020-06-25.snippet: Florida, Texas, Oklahoma and South Carolina set daily records. Nationwide, more than 36,000 cases were reported Wednesday.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, governors, mayors, investors and others across the United States woke up to news that was impossible to ignore. More than 35,000 new coronavirus cases had been identified the day before. It was the highest number reported in a single day since late April.
2020-06-25.headline_main: Coronavirus Surge Raises Alarm as States Report New Highs

2020-06-25.abstract: A man of manifold interests, his achievements ranged from developing ideas behind the so-called Internet of Things to publishing the world’s biggest book.
2020-06-25.snippet: A man of manifold interests, his achievements ranged from developing ideas behind the so-called Internet of Things to publishing the world’s biggest book.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: Michael Hawley, a computer programmer, professor, musician, speechwriter and impresario who helped lay the intellectual groundwork for what is now called the Internet of Things, died on Wednesday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 58.

2020-06-25.abstract: Pregnant women who are infected wind up in hospitals and I.C.U.’s at higher rates, a federal analysis suggests. But the data is far from conclusive.
2020-06-25.snippet: Pregnant women who are infected wind up in hospitals and I.C.U.’s at higher rates, a federal analysis suggests. But the data is far from conclusive.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: Pregnant women infected with the coronavirus are more likely to be hospitalized, admitted to an intensive care unit and put on a ventilator than are infected women who are not pregnant, according to a new government analysis.

2020-06-25.snippet: Amanda Chung and Karl Ni offer us a part of themselves.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Many solvers ask how they are supposed to know when there is “funny business” going on in the grid. The short answer is to practice, so you will be exposed to a variety of puzzle tricks and learn to recognize them. I’ve heard from a lot of solvers who don’t seem to have the patience for that. They would like there to be a visible warning near the grid to tip them off.
2020-06-25.headline_main: ‘We Shall Overcome’

2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic is still raging in this country. In fact, in more than 20 states, the number of cases is rising. 2020-06-25.abstract: A Chinese city is rolling out the database to allow people to check if their partners have a history of abuse. Domestic violence has been exacerbated by lockdowns during the coronavirus pandemic.
2020-06-25.snippet: A Chinese city is rolling out the database to allow people to check if their partners have a history of abuse. Domestic violence has been exacerbated by lockdowns during the coronavirus pandemic.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: A city in eastern China is preparing to roll out a database that would allow people getting married to check if their prospective partner has a history of domestic violence, in what’s being called the first of its kind in the country.
2020-06-25.headline_main: For Those Getting Married, a Searchable Domestic Violence Database

2020-06-25.abstract: “Search Party” is back, now on HBO Max. And the second season of “The Twilight Zone” debuts on CBS All Access.
2020-06-25.snippet: “Search Party” is back, now on HBO Max. And the second season of “The Twilight Zone” debuts on CBS All Access.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: SEARCH PARTY Stream on HBO Max. “Could these hipsters be coldblooded murderers?” That question is posed by a news anchor in a trailer for the new, third season of this dark comedy series. The show stars Alia Shawkat as Dory, a millennial who lives in Brooklyn. The first season followed her and a group of fellow Brooklynites investigating a disappearance; the second season involved a killing. After a couple years off, Dory and company are back, this time on HBO’s new streaming service (the show was on TBS). Season 3 includes a high-stakes criminal trial, chic clothes and cynicism. “‘Search Party,’ has always had a retro-tinged aesthetic, a slight thrift-store defect to its world, which makes it feel surreal at times — part of reality but not identical to it,” Margaret Lyons wrote in a recent edition of The New York Times’s Watching newsletter. “Teasing out the contrast between the weightlessness of an imagined, curated past and the cruel density of the flawed, lived past is one of the show’s most elegant tricks.”
2020-06-25.headline_main: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Search Party’ and ‘The Twilight Zone’

2020-06-25.abstract: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
2020-06-25.snippet: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.

2020-06-25.abstract: A small faction of players — less than 4 percent in the 2018-19 season — play in all 82 games in a season. They have had to adjust to some rare downtime with the N.B.A. shut down by the pandemic.
2020-06-25.snippet: A small faction of players — less than 4 percent in the 2018-19 season — play in all 82 games in a season. They have had to adjust to some rare downtime with the N.B.A. shut down by the pandemic.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: Little will be ordinary when the abbreviated 2019-20 N.B.A. season resumes as expected on July 30. Games will be played at the Walt Disney World Resort inside a so-called bubble, a plan that does away with playoff basketball’s normal hallmarks of rigorous travel, home-court advantage and the motivational fuel provided by screaming fans.

2020-06-25.abstract: On June 1, SWAT teams turned a protest march in Philadelphia into chaos. We went to the site, interviewed witnesses and analyzed dozens of videos to reconstruct what happened.
2020-06-25.snippet: On June 1, SWAT teams turned a protest march in Philadelphia into chaos. We went to the site, interviewed witnesses and analyzed dozens of videos to reconstruct what happened.

2020-06-25.abstract: For a century, quantum theory has been scientific orthodoxy. The Italian physicist Angelo Bassi is certain it isn’t the full story — and that he can prove it.
2020-06-25.snippet: For a century, quantum theory has been scientific orthodoxy. The Italian physicist Angelo Bassi is certain it isn’t the full story — and that he can prove it.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: ‘The thing that amazes me is that quantum mechanics is only 100 years old,” the physicist Angelo Bassi said. We were in conversation across a picnic table on a drab Soviet-era campus in Zagreb, an early-autumn breeze swishing through the yellowing leaves of some nearby trees. “It’s a baby, it’s nothing — 100 years in the history of science. How can you just stop there? It doesn’t make sense any way you look at it.” We sat in the shadow of a rust-stained beige building where Bassi was about to speak at a workshop for physicists who specialize in the century-old subject.
2020-06-25.headline_main: The Rebel Physicist on the Hunt for a Better Story Than Quantum Mechanics

2020-06-25.abstract: We’re being collected somewhere on video and in memory — and maybe we want to be.
2020-06-25.snippet: We’re being collected somewhere on video and in memory — and maybe we want to be.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: “Ganbatte” is Japanese for “hold out, persevere, do your best.” In the spring of 2020, those concepts took on new meaning for everyone — as did the concept of donning a ski mask and jumping through any door. Sarah Kortemeier’s poem from her mesmerizing debut collection, “Ganbatte,” offers a new twist on vigilance. We’re being collected somewhere on video and in memory, at all times, and maybe we want to be. Balcony waves are not quite enough. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye
2020-06-25.headline_main: Poem: Surveillance

2020-06-25.abstract: Her videos pull back the curtain on a president who, amid historic crises, has found almost nothing meaningful to say.
2020-06-25.snippet: Her videos pull back the curtain on a president who, amid historic crises, has found almost nothing meaningful to say.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: When Sarah Cooper lip-syncs Donald Trump’s news conferences, there’s no lectern or presidential seal. There’s no Mike Pence, face calibrated to Placid Gratitude as he gazes beatifically into the middle distance, and no Dr. Anthony Fauci, looking as though he’d give anything to be transported someplace better, like maybe Edvard Munch’s “The Scream.” No, in Cooper’s version there’s just Cooper, posting videos online, usually from her own apartment, miming along to the president’s characteristic rasp — part pontificating doorman, part tepid Marlon Brando impersonation, grasping from one excuse to another, one enemy to another, one wrecking ball to another.
2020-06-25.headline_main: Sarah Cooper Doesn’t Mimic Trump. She Exposes Him.

2020-06-25.abstract: Why the great Russian novelist’s critique of state-sponsored violence bears thinking about now.
2020-06-25.snippet: Why the great Russian novelist’s critique of state-sponsored violence bears thinking about now.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: In the early months of lockdown, many people stuck at home found themselves turning to unusual sources of comfort: Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s PowerPoint presentations, bread-baking (especially, for reasons unclear, sourdough) and “War and Peace,” Leo Tolstoy’s 1,200-page novel about the Napoleonic era in Russia.
2020-06-25.headline_main: Leo Tolstoy vs. the Police

2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: On June 11th, my 38th birthday, I found myself head-to-head in a virtual rowing race against the 23-year-old rowing champion Oliver Zeidler. Me, a father of two who has been rowing in his garage for three years, against Olli. Ridiculous.
2020-06-25.headline_main: Racing a World-Champion Rower in My Garage

2020-06-25.abstract: The best-selling author and former minority leader for the Georgia House of Representatives has a lot going on, but she still makes time for fiction.
2020-06-25.snippet: The best-selling author and former minority leader for the Georgia House of Representatives has a lot going on, but she still makes time for fiction.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: WOMAN OF WORDS The last thing Stacey Abrams, who is a Democrat, wanted to do was write a memoir about losing the 2018 Georgia gubernatorial race to the Republican, Brian Kemp. She says the idea came up, but “it was not appealing to me. As someone who has spent my adult life working on issues of access, justice and voting rights, I wanted to figure out, what could I say that was necessary? That told readers, here’s what we have to know, so history doesn’t repeat itself. I come from a family where our parents told us, if you see a problem, your job is to fix it. Writing is how I work through how to fix it.”
2020-06-25.headline_main: Want to Be in Stacey Abrams’s Book Club? Sorry, It’s Family Only

2020-06-25.abstract: American coronavirus testing remains fragmented, as in the early days of the pandemic, and the bottlenecks are the same ones, too.

On Friday, Arizona’s largest laboratory received twice as many samples as it could process. The phone line for testing appointments at a large site on the state fairgrounds now opens at 7 a.m. with 800 callers already in the queue.

2020-06-25.abstract: During lockdown, some women gave in to the joy of going braless. Others were buying seductive underwear.
2020-06-25.snippet: During lockdown, some women gave in to the joy of going braless. Others were buying seductive underwear.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: When lockdown began a few months ago, as some women adopted sweatpants and worn-in tees as a virtual uniform, others were buying apparel that’s considerably more alluring: lacy push-up bras, slinky thongs and other undergarments that are more characteristically reserved for P.P.E.-free, socially undistanced activities.

2020-06-25.abstract: You can read or write a book from home just fine. Publishing one, however, remains a very social activity.

2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: During a normal week, Jordan Pavlin, the editorial director at Knopf, seldom ate at her desk. Depending on the day, she might be meeting with literary agents over lunch, catching up with an author over an after-work drink, or having a quick bite before a cocktail party for a newly released title.
2020-06-25.headline_main: Books Are a Great Fit for Quarantine. The Book Business, Not So Much.

2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: The United States faces an economic downturn without precedent. Is it also a moment that could produce lasting change?

2020-06-25.abstract: Recent research indicates little progress since the Truman administration.
2020-06-25.snippet: Recent research indicates little progress since the Truman administration.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: That’s remarkable. Despite decades of political change — the end of enforced segregation across the South, the legalization of interracial marriage, the passage of multiple civil rights laws and more — the wages of black men trail those of white men by as much as when Harry Truman was president. That gap indicates that there have also been powerful forces pushing against racial equality.
2020-06-25.headline_main: The Black-White Wage Gap Is as Big as It Was in 1950

2020-06-25.abstract: Hitting the open road can be fraught for some black Americans, who share their anxieties of racist targeting. For others, getting behind the wheel is freedom.
2020-06-25.snippet: Hitting the open road can be fraught for some black Americans, who share their anxieties of racist targeting. For others, getting behind the wheel is freedom.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: The road trip has long been considered part of the great American experience, but the feeling of freedom often associated with getting in a car and seeing the country hasn’t always been extended to African-American travelers, who often worry about discrimination and racism while traveling.
2020-06-25.headline_main: Road Tripping While Black: Readers Respond

2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: When Kansas State opened the doors to its athletic facilities, welcoming its football players back to campus starting the first weekend in June, administrators breathed a sigh of relief once the first batch of coronavirus tests came back.
2020-06-25.headline_main: This College Football Team Had No Coronavirus Cases at First. Then It Shut Down.

2020-06-25.abstract: A New York Times/Siena College poll paints a grim picture for Republicans in Arizona, Michigan and North Carolina as voters shun candidates aligned with the president.
2020-06-25.snippet: A New York Times/Siena College poll paints a grim picture for Republicans in Arizona, Michigan and North Carolina as voters shun candidates aligned with the president.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s erratic performance in office and his deteriorating standing in the polls is posing a grave threat to his party’s Senate majority, imperiling incumbents in crucial swing states and undermining Republican prospects in one of the few states they had hoped to gain a seat, according to a new poll of registered voters by The New York Times and Siena College.

2020-06-25.abstract: Since the 1980s, profit-sharing has declined. It deserves to make a comeback.
2020-06-25.snippet: Since the 1980s, profit-sharing has declined. It deserves to make a comeback.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: After the bruising crises we’re now going through, it would be wonderful if we could somehow emerge a fairer nation. One possibility is to revive an old idea: sharing the profits.

2020-06-25.abstract: The nightly booms, bangs and fizzles have intensified to such a degree that some New York residents are adopting increasingly far-fetched theories about their source.
2020-06-25.snippet: The nightly booms, bangs and fizzles have intensified to such a degree that some New York residents are adopting increasingly far-fetched theories about their source.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: When Anne-Marcelle Ngabirano first began hearing the fireworks at the end of May, she found them to be welcome sounds of celebration. But over the next few weeks, they sounded closer and closer to her three-bedroom apartment in Sunset Park, until the booms began rattling the walls and the apartment filled with smoke.
2020-06-25.headline_main: Fireworks Conspiracy Theories: Why You Should Be Skeptical

2020-06-25.abstract: Donors have given more than $90 million to help buy the freedom of those awaiting trial behind bars.
2020-06-25.snippet: Donors have given more than $90 million to help buy the freedom of those awaiting trial behind bars.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: One afternoon in June, Elisabeth Epps hopped into her partner’s Jeep and rode from Denver to Boulder, carrying cashier’s checks worth nearly $16,000.
2020-06-25.headline_main: Bail Funds, Flush With Cash, Learn to ‘Grind Through This Horrible Process’

2020-06-25.abstract: Descendants of Robert E. Lee and others whose statues are coming down are confronting this moment’s reassessment of history in a very personal way.
2020-06-25.snippet: Descendants of Robert E. Lee and others whose statues are coming down are confronting this moment’s reassessment of history in a very personal way.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: Clayton Wickham, 28, said he used to think of the statue of his great-great-great-grandfather as “just a statue that had my name on it that was kind of cool to walk by every now and then.”
2020-06-25.headline_main: When the Toppled Statue Is of Your Great-Great-Great-Grandfather

2020-06-25.abstract: Yearbook and high school newspaper editors have spent the past few months trying to preserve traditions upended by the coronavirus.
2020-06-25.snippet: Yearbook and high school newspaper editors have spent the past few months trying to preserve traditions upended by the coronavirus.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: No spring sports. No long-awaited trips abroad or senior spirit week. Proms delayed indefinitely, and graduations switched to Zoom.
2020-06-25.headline_main: How These Students Lost, and Recaptured, the Magic of Senior Year

2020-06-25.abstract: Herbal formulas are also a potion for national cohesion.
2020-06-25.snippet: Herbal formulas are also a potion for national cohesion.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — “The motherland is by your side” read the message printed on the plastic envelope. The characters were set in bright yellow against a crimson background, the same colors as on China’s national flag. “Genuine affection from 10,000 miles away.”
2020-06-25.headline_main: A Coronavirus Care Package From China

2020-06-25.abstract: An increase in remote workers won’t automatically usher in a gender-equal utopia. If we want it, we have to make it so.
2020-06-25.snippet: An increase in remote workers won’t automatically usher in a gender-equal utopia. If we want it, we have to make it so.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: Ever since the coronavirus pandemic began keeping most of us sheltered at home, work has rapidly shifted from the cubicle to the kitchen table. A number of surveys indicate that about half of the American work force is now doing their work at home. Companies that may have once been resistant to letting employees off the in-person leash are finding that yes, work can still get done outside the confines of an office building.
2020-06-25.headline_main: Write a Book? Sure, Work From Home. Care for a Child? Nope.

2020-06-25.abstract: A theme park’s whiz-bang performances are an odd mix of high-quality production values and one-dimensional storytelling. Historians have long disputed the narratives.
2020-06-25.snippet: A theme park’s whiz-bang performances are an odd mix of high-quality production values and one-dimensional storytelling. Historians have long disputed the narratives.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: LES EPESSES, France — While most French theaters remain closed and live sports won’t resume until July, there is one arena in the country where thousands can already sit down to watch a show. In a Roman-style amphitheater at the Puy du Fou, a historical theme park in western France, gladiators in period costumes have been performing daily since June 11.
2020-06-25.headline_main: Some of France’s Only Live Theater Right Now Is a Historical Affront

2020-06-25.abstract: The U.S. reported more than 41,000 new cases on Thursday, the second consecutive day with a record total, and the C.D.C. said the true national caseload was probably 10 times the official count. India plans to test all 29 million residents of its capital for the virus.
2020-06-25.snippet: The U.S. reported more than 41,000 new cases on Thursday, the second consecutive day with a record total, and the C.D.C. said the true national caseload was probably 10 times the official count. India plans to test all 29 million residents of its ...
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: The United States on Thursday reported more than 41,000 new coronavirus cases, a record  total for the second straight day, as a nationwide sense of urgency grew and caseloads soared in Southern and Western states that were far removed from the worst early outbreaks.
2020-06-25.headline_main: As New Coronavirus Cases Hit Another Record in the U.S., Some States Delay Reopenings

2020-06-25.abstract: “Aunt Nellie’s Diary” was penned by the famous author when she was only 17. It has been published for the first time in The Strand Magazine.
2020-06-25.snippet: “Aunt Nellie’s Diary” was penned by the famous author when she was only 17. It has been published for the first time in The Strand Magazine.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: A previously unpublished piece by Louisa May Alcott, the author best known for her novel “Little Women,” is now available in print for the first time.
2020-06-25.headline_main: The Ending of This Louisa May Alcott Story May Disappoint You

2020-06-25.abstract: The Hot Cars Act of 2019 is part of legislation the House will soon consider. It’s long overdue, say advocates of technology that alerts owners.
2020-06-25.snippet: The Hot Cars Act of 2019 is part of legislation the House will soon consider. It’s long overdue, say advocates of technology that alerts owners.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: There was reason for optimism last June. The Hot Cars Act of 2019 appeared to be making some progress. The bill would require a device that could warn drivers and car owners of a child left behind in a car or one who had gotten into a parked car.
2020-06-25.headline_main: Momentum for an Effort to Save Children From Sweltering Cars

2020-06-25.abstract: In six states crucial to the president’s election hopes, our polling found a potentially decisive shift in opinion.
2020-06-25.snippet: In six states crucial to the president’s election hopes, our polling found a potentially decisive shift in opinion.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
2020-06-25.headline_main: The Voters Trump Is Losing

2020-06-25.abstract: The German electronic payments company, where $2.1 billion went missing, cited “impending insolvency and over-indebtedness.”
2020-06-25.snippet: The German electronic payments company, where $2.1 billion went missing, cited “impending insolvency and over-indebtedness.”
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: Wirecard, the troubled German company that became embroiled in a scandal over a missing $2.1 billion, said on Thursday that it would file for insolvency.
2020-06-25.headline_main: Wirecard, Reeling From Accounting Scandal, Files for Insolvency

2020-06-25.abstract: And what else you need to know today.
2020-06-25.snippet: And what else you need to know today.
2020-06-25.lead_paragraph: One remarkable sign of the racial inequities plaguing the United States: The wage gap between black and white men is as large today as it was in 1950.
2020-06-25.headline_main: The Enormous Black-White Wage Gap

2020-06-25.abstract: The I.M.F. cut its forecasts and warned of “scarring” to the global economy, as a surge of coronavirus infections sows doubts about the recovery.
